ChapterText:
Dawn had barely broken when the thunderous knocking shattered the morning silence. Moren’s heart lurched as someone flung open the kitchen door downstairs with a bang. He heard shouts, heavy footsteps trudging up the narrow wooden staircase.


Barely a breath later, the silhouettes of two guards filled the frame of his bedroom door. His daughter Siva, that had been sleeping peacefully curled up in his arms a moment ago, clutched her doll closer, her young eyes widening with fear. Before Moren could react, rough hands seized him, pulled him up from his bed and pinned his arms behind his back. He struggled; his eyes locked on Siva as the guard grabbed her. “Papa!” she screamed, reaching out towards him.


They pushed him down the staircase; he tumbled into his kitchen and landed roughly on the stone floor, a splitting pain shot through his head, and he felt dizzy. He tried to look around, tried to see what was going on, how many there were, tried to remember what had happened the day before that had given them away.


Before he could gather his thoughts, the guards seized him and forcefully pulled him out through the front door, onto the porch, and into the dusty streets. His desperate pleas for mercy drowned in the jeers of the crowd that had gathered. The town square, usually a place of commerce and laughter, had transformed into a theater of justice; or so the Church proclaimed. They had erected stakes in the center, which stood ominously and cruelly against the pale morning sky.


The guard that had grabbed his little girl strode past him, holding Siva by her wrist. He could see her struggling against their grip. He marched her to the stakes and tied her to one of them, her slight frame swallowed by the rough ropes he wound around her. Moren’s voice broke as he shouted and threw his weight against the guards holding him, trying to get to her, but the guard forced him to his knees with a kick to the legs and held his head up by the hair, forcing him to witness the horror unfolding.


The Inquisitor stepped forward, his voice booming as he declared the charges against the three accused women and children standing bound to the stakes. “Witchcraft! Wild magic! An abomination and an attack against the Divine Light!” He wrapped his hand around the tar-soaked tip of the torch he was holding. He seemed to whisper to it, then it burst into flames. The crowd cheered; their faces twisted in a macabre grin of righteousness. Moren’s desperate howls mingled with Siva’s whimpering.


“No, please, not my little girl!” His voice was raw. “This is not justice!”

“Shut it!” a guard snarled at him and kicked him square in the head.

His vision blurred, but he kept struggling and screaming, clenching his fists.

“I. Said. Shut. It.” He punctuated each word with a blow to Moren’s head.


The last thing he saw was the torch moving towards his daughter. The last thing he heard was Siva’s screaming. Her cry pierced his heart like a dagger. The last thing he felt was a searing heat that pushed through the square as his daughter’s terror erupted, raw and uncontrollable.


A ripple that knocked the guards back and extinguished the torches of onlookers. Moren felt it in his chest, like his heart stumbled, and he tasted burning wood. His vision blurred around the edges, and he felt darkness creeping over him. His eyes closed, and he fell into helpless, broken unconsciousness. As he woke, the smell of burned flesh overwhelmed his senses. A vile testament to the cruelty humanity was capable of. His eyes stung, and he was covered in ash. He tried to sit up but failed. The spectacle was over. The fires had turned to swirling clouds of dust.


The crowd had dispersed, their thirst for justice satiated, their hearts untouched by the brutality they had just witnessed. Moren crawled to the blackened stake his daughter had been tied to. There were no tears left in him to fall on the charred ground that held her remains. “I’m so sorry,” he murmured, choking on dry sobs. His hands dug into the still hot dirt as if he could somehow uncover something of her that was not ravaged by flames.


He curled up on the pile of ashes that was slowly carried away by the wind. Moren’s life as he knew it had ended with hers. What was left was a shell, a father haunted by the echoes of his daughter’s screams, his very soul scorched by the righteous fires of the faith’s justice. He heard heavy steps approaching, but he couldn’t move, couldn’t care. He felt something heavy strike his head, and he collapsed into darkness.
ToDo: Story Advancement & Key Plot Points • Establishes the world’s dangers immediately—magic is a crime punishable by death. • Introduces the Church as an overwhelming, unquestioned authority. • Sets up Moren’s loss and later motivation for rebellion. • Shows how deeply ingrained the Church’s doctrine is—the crowd cheers. Conflicts & Obstacles • Moren is outnumbered and powerless. • The Church has absolute control over public perception. • The pyres symbolize the erasure of Wild Magic. Moren’s Emotional & Psychological Change • Starts as a father protecting his daughter, by the end, he is a broken man. • His faith in people is shattered. • His rage and grief fuel his later role in resistance. High Moment / Key Visuals (What the Reader Sees & Feels) The fire ignites. Moren screams, trying to break free. Siva’s terror surges—an unseen force ripples through the air. The torches of the crowd flicker, snuffed out for a brief moment. Then the flames roar, drowning everything. Moren is struck down, the world fading into darkness. Hidden Truths (What the Reader Doesn’t Know Yet) • Siva was never burned • The Church stole Siva, faking her death. • She is renamed Lia and raised as a Divine Magician in the Order of Flame • Moren passes out before seeing what really happened. Ending Scene Visual (Final Moments of the Chapter) Moren’s body lies in the ashes, unmoving. The morning sun rises over Sovalis, cold and indifferent. The square is empty now, except for the smoldering remains of the stakes. The world moves on. But for Moren, nothing will ever be the same. Questions for Refinement 1. Do you want to hint at the moment Siva is taken (a shadowy figure, a brief glimpse of a hooded Church member), or completely conceal it until later? 2. Should Moren have one last whispered word or thought before losing consciousness? 3. Do you want to show more of the Inquisitor and his role, or keep him a faceless embodiment of the Church’s will?

ChapterTitle: Chapter 1: The Birth of a Prince
ChapterText:
Overall Chapter Summary:
The kingdom eagerly awaits the birth of its heir, a moment of joy and celebration. However, the event is marked by tragedy when Queen Marielle dies in childbirth. King Alistair, stricken with grief but holding his newborn son, clings to the promise of a strong future for his child. A year later, the court gathers to celebrate the prince’s first birthday, but the absence of the queen casts a shadow over the festivities.

Scene 1: A Kingdom Awaits

Location: The Royal Palace, The City of Sheen – Grand Hall
Time of Day: Evening
Time of Year: Autumn, Irrst Month
Weather: Crisp air, the first signs of falling leaves
POV Character: A court noble (or a midwife, to give an outsider’s perspective)
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: Unknown (this is the opening of a new chapter)

Scene Summary:

Anxious energy filled the palace. The kingdom has awaited this moment for years—the birth of an heir. Courtiers whisper, some praying in the chapel while others drink in celebration. The people of Sovalis light lanterns in the streets, eager to welcome their future king. The Church has given its blessing, proclaiming the child’s birth as a divine sign of prosperity.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • Establishes hope and joy surrounding the prince’s birth.

  • Shows the strong relationship between the monarchy and the Church.

  • Introduces the weight of expectation on the future heir.

Conflicts & Obstacles:

  • A tense atmosphere as the birth takes longer than expected.

  • Rumors spread—some fear for the queen’s life, while others dismiss such worries.

How the Scene Changes the POV Character:

  • They start optimistic and excited but begin feeling unease as time passes.

High Moment / Key Info:

  • The announcement is delayed longer than expected, setting up tension.

Scene 2: The Prince is Born, The Queen is Lost

Location: The Royal Bedchamber
Time of Day: Late Night
Time of Year: Same Night, Autumn, Irrst Month
Weather: Wind picking up, storm approaching
POV Character: King Alistair
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

Scene Summary:

Inside the royal bedchamber, Queen Marielle’s screams have quieted. The midwives move frantically, voices hushed, trying to stop the bleeding. King Alistair enters just in time to see his wife take her last breath. The midwife places the newborn in his arms—his son. The joy of birth is overshadowed by unbearable grief.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • The queen’s death changes the king forever—introducing his fear of losing control.

  • Belon stirs for the first time, sensing the grief and pain.

  • Edric’s fate is already being shaped—he is born into both love and loss.

Conflicts & Obstacles:

  • The midwives fail to save the queen despite their efforts.

  • The king must face both his son’s birth and his wife’s death in the same moment.

How the Scene Changes the King:

  • He enters full of hope but leaves with his world shattered.

High Moment / Key Info:

  • As the queen exhales her final breath, the newborn lets out his first cry—symbolizing life and death entwined.

Scene 3: A Father’s Promise

Location: The Royal Chambers, Alistair’s Private Quarters
Time of Day: Near Dawn
Time of Year: Same Night, Autumn, Irrst Month
Weather: Rain has begun, tapping against the windows
POV Character: King Alistair
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

Scene Summary:

The palace is silent except for the occasional cry of the newborn prince. King Alistair sits in the dim light of his chambers, cradling his son. He speaks to him, promising to build a world where he will be strong and safe. His grief is held back by sheer determination—this child is all that remains of Marielle, and he will not fail him.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • Establishes the king’s growing fear of the world’s dangers.

  • Introduces the idea that Edric must be protected at all costs.

  • The king feels a need to take stronger control over the kingdom, beginning his path toward tightening Church influence.

Conflicts & Obstacles:

  • The king struggles between grief and responsibility.

  • The weight of ruling alone begins pressing on him.

How the Scene Changes the King:

  • He starts as a grieving husband and ends as a determined father.

High Moment / Key Info:

  • The king makes an unspoken decision—he will ensure no threat ever touches his son.

Scene 4: The Prince’s First Birthday

Location: The Grand Hall of the Palace
Time of Day: Afternoon
Time of Year: One Year Later, Autumn, Irrst Month
Weather: A crisp, golden autumn day
POV Character: A noblewoman attending the feast
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: One year

Scene Summary:

The court gathers for Prince Edric’s first birthday feast. Gold banners hang, music plays, and food is plentiful. But despite the celebration, there is a quiet tension—the queen’s absence is felt by all. Some raise toasts in her honor, while others avoid speaking of her entirely.

King Alistair presents Edric to the court, but his joy is measured, almost restrained. There is a moment when he looks at the empty throne beside him, and for a fleeting second, his mask slips.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • The kingdom adores its young prince, but something is missing.

  • The king grows colder, beginning his slow shift into paranoia.

  • Hints of Edric’s unnatural stillness as a child—he rarely cries, his eyes are unnervingly sharp.

Conflicts & Obstacles:

  • The celebration feels hollow without the queen.

  • The king forces himself to focus on the future, avoiding his grief.

How the Scene Changes the King:

  • He begins isolating himself emotionally, focusing entirely on securing the future.

High Moment / Key Info:

  • A priest from the Church assures Alistair that the prince is blessed by the Divine Light.

  • Belon’s whispers stir again—Edric watches the flames of the candles with fascination.

Scene 4: A King’s Burden

Location: Council Chamber, Royal Palace, Sovalis
Time of Day: Late Afternoon
Time of Year: Winter, Jart Month
Weather: Bitter cold, overcast skies, snow beginning to fall
POV Character: King Alistair
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few months

Scene Summary

King Alistair sits at the head of the long council table, his expression unreadable as his advisors deliver troubling reports. His kingdom is uneasy—small uprisings have broken out in the countryside, driven by fear and resentment toward the Church’s growing authority. More disturbing are the reports of strange natural occurrences—violent storms, sudden droughts, rivers flooding at the wrong season. The advisors argue over whether this is divine punishment or the result of magicians tampering with nature.

Among them is Inquisitor Varick, a sharp, ambitious clergyman who has steadily gained influence in court. He is composed, confident, and persuasive, his words laced with subtle threats and reassurances. He argues that the only way to protect the kingdom from further chaos is to give the Order of Flame unrestricted authority to root out Wild Magicians before their influence spreads.

The council is divided, some hesitant to grant the Church more power, others seeing it as a necessity. The king listens, silent for most of the debate. He is already leaning toward allowing the Inquisitors more freedom, but he does not want to appear weak.

Varick presses his advantage, subtly framing this decision as not just a political necessity, but a father’s duty. He reminds Alistair that the future king must inherit a kingdom that is stable, unchallenged by rogue magicians and rebels.

At last, the king speaks. The Order of Flame will have fewer restrictions. Their reach will extend beyond just towns and cities—they will be allowed to investigate rural villages, noble estates, even the outskirts of Sovalis itself. The council is dismissed, and the king lingers, staring into the fire, the weight of his decision pressing down on him.

The scene ends on a somber note—he tells himself he is doing this for his son, but there is an undeniable unease growing in his heart.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Introduces Inquisitor Varick, an influential clergyman and political manipulator.

  • Establishes rising unrest in the kingdom—the public is uneasy with the Church’s growing control.

  • Highlights the first signs of magical imbalance—the environment itself is responding to the persecution of magic.

  • King Alistair grants the Order of Flame greater freedom, setting the stage for the Church’s rise to near-total authority.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • The council is divided—some believe in controlling magic, others worry about unchecked Church power.

  • The King fears losing control, torn between his personal doubts and political necessity.

  • Varick subtly manipulates the king, framing the decision as protecting his son’s legacy.

How the Scene Changes the King

  • Alistair enters the meeting already worried but still in control.

  • He leaves having given up a significant amount of power to the Church, something he will later regret.

  • His justification—that this is for his son—feels hollow, but he clings to it.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • Natural disasters are worsening, signaling that magic itself is being thrown off balance.

  • The Order of Flame is given greater authority, marking the next phase in the Church’s consolidation of power.

  • Varick is rising in influence, positioning himself as the king’s most trusted advisor.

Ending Scene Visual (Final Moments of the Scene)

  • The council chamber empties, but the king remains seated. The firelight flickers against the polished wood, his face half-shadowed.

  • Outside the palace, the wind howls, and the first snow begins to fall—a quiet omen of what is to come.

Scene 1: A Quiet Moment Before the Storm

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Lower District of Sovalis
Time of Day: Late Afternoon
Time of Year: Late Spring, Chana Month
Weather: Crisp air, golden sunlight filtering through the windows, the last remnants of winter still clinging to the breeze
POV Character: Mirah
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few months

Scene Summary

The small home is filled with the scent of simmering stew, warm despite the cool air outside. Mirah stands at the hearth, stirring with slow, practiced movements, her rounded belly making even simple motions feel heavier. Aelius enters, brushing specks of charcoal from his hands and beard, his fingers still stained with the ink and paint of the day’s work. Without hesitation, he moves to her, wrapping his arms around her from behind, pressing a kiss into the crook of her neck.

Their conversation is soft, intimate—a husband and wife sharing a moment of normalcy despite the world closing in around them.

Aelius speaks first of the trouble in the city—fights breaking out in the markets, whispers of magicians being dragged from their homes at night. He saw an Inquisitor standing in the square today, cloaked in red, surrounded by armed men. The grip of the Order of Flame has tightened since the King granted them more freedom, and now, people disappear without warning. Even those who simply knew a Wild Magician are being questioned, accused.

Mirah listens, her hands resting protectively over her belly. They both know their child will be born into a dangerous world, and she voices the fear neither of them have dared to say aloud—what if their child is born with magic?

Aelius, ever the optimist, brushes the thought away with a laugh. “He will be fierce,” he says confidently, as if sheer determination will make it so.

Mirah smiles at him, arching a brow. “And why are you so convinced it will be a ‘he’? Will he be born with a beard like yours, then?”

Their laughter fills the small home, chasing away the weight of their fears, if only for a moment. The warmth of their love and the safety of their house make the outside world feel distant—but the reader knows this peace cannot last.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Introduces Aelius and Mirah as loving, hopeful parents-to-be, despite their fears.

  • Provides worldbuilding through Aelius’ firsthand account of the worsening situation in Sovalis.

  • Reinforces the rising power of the Order of Flame following the King’s recent decision.

  • Establishes the looming fear of what will happen if their child is born with magic.

  • Gives a moment of lighthearted banter to make their eventual tragedy more painful.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • The city is becoming more dangerous, even for those who stay silent.

  • The Order of Flame is no longer just hunting Wild Magicians, but anyone connected to them.

  • Aelius tries to protect Mirah from the truth of how bad things are, but she sees through him.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Mirah begins confronting the reality of their situation, realizing there is no escaping what’s coming.

  • Aelius, despite his fears, clings to hope. He is determined to protect his family, even if he does not yet realize he will be unable to.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • The first time the Order of Flame’s authority is seen in action, not just talked about.

  • Aelius and Mirah’s deep love for one another is made clear, heightening the impact of their eventual fate.

  • Their conversation subtly foreshadows Arana’s fierce nature—Aelius’ words unknowingly predicting the daughter he will never see grow up.

Ending Scene Visual (Final Moments of the Scene)

  • Aelius rests a calloused hand over Mirah’s belly, his other hand still streaked with ink.

  • Outside, the sun is beginning to set, casting long shadows over Sovalis.

  • The city is changing, darkening, but inside their home, it is still warm.

 

Scene 2: The Birth of Arana

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Lower District of Sovalis
Time of Day: Just before dawn
Time of Year: Summer, Fram Month
Weather: Cool morning air, the scent of wet stone from a night rain
POV Character: Mirah
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few months

Scene Summary

Mirah lies in bed, her breath coming in slow, exhausted intervals. The small room is dimly lit by a single lantern, its glow reflecting in the sheen of sweat on her skin. She is too tired to cry, too drained to do anything but look at the bundle in her arms—the child she has carried through fear, through months of unrest, through uncertainty.

A girl.

Aelius kneels beside the bed, his rough artist’s hands trembling as he brushes a thumb over the baby’s small, wrinkled fingers. There is no disappointment in his face, only awe. She is not the son he imagined, but she is perfect.

“She will be fierce,” he whispers, repeating the words he spoke months ago. Mirah lets out a weak laugh, voice hoarse. “With or without a beard?”

Aelius grins, but there is something else in his expression—a silent promise. He will protect her, no matter the cost.

Outside, the first light of dawn creeps into the sky, golden against the rooftops of Sovalis. The city is waking, unaware that it now holds a child who will one day stand against the very forces tightening their grip upon it.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Arana is born. This is the moment her story truly begins.

  • Aelius’ unwavering love for his daughter is established. He never mourns that she is not a son—he only sees her as his child.

  • Subtle foreshadowing of Arana’s strength, through Aelius’ repeated words.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Mirah is weak from labor, but they cannot afford a midwife. They have had to rely on secrecy, avoiding attention.

  • Aelius is both overjoyed and afraid. The city is dangerous, and now he has more to lose than ever before.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Aelius’ protectiveness deepens. His determination to keep his family safe will later lead to choices that seal their fate.

  • Mirah, despite exhaustion, feels a fierce love for her daughter, pushing aside all fear for this one moment.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • Aelius’ words echo his earlier prediction, unknowingly solidifying Arana’s destiny.

  • The scene establishes that magic in children remains dormant until age 10, a key world-building detail.

Ending Scene Visual (Final Moments of the Scene)

  • Aelius watches the morning light touch Arana’s tiny face, his heart full of love and worry in equal measure.

  • In the distance, the city stirs, but here, in this quiet home, nothing else matters.

Scene 3: A Father’s Story

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Lower District of Sovalis
Time of Day: Late evening, just before Arana’s bedtime
Time of Year: Summer, Fram Month
Weather: A warm breeze through the open window, the scent of the river in the distance
POV Character: Arana (toddler perspective)
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: Three years

Scene Summary

The small room is dim except for the flickering glow of the fireplace. Arana sits on her father’s lap, eyes wide, enraptured by his words. She is too young to understand everything, but the way he speaks—the rise and fall of his voice, the movement of his hands—holds her spellbound.

Aelius tells her a tale of the ancient gods, the forces of fire and storm, earth and sea, who once walked the world in harmony with humankind. His hands move, and with them, tiny sparks dance through the air, trailing behind his fingers like fireflies. Light blooms and fades, shifting with the story. Arana gasps, reaching out with tiny hands, but the sparks flit away like living things.

Mirah, leaning against the doorframe, watches with a small smile. She never stops Aelius from using magic at home—not when it is just them.

But she reminds him, always, to be careful.

Aelius meets his wife’s eyes over Arana’s head. “She deserves to know,” he says softly, letting the last of the sparks fade.

Arana stares in wonder. She does not yet understand the meaning of the story, or the power behind it. But the warmth of the magic stays with her, embedding itself in her earliest memories.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • First instance of magic seen through Arana’s perspective, setting up her later connection to it.

  • Aelius wants his daughter to know the truth about magic, even in secret.

  • Mirah is cautious, but does not stop him—she, too, remembers a time when magic was not feared.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Aelius’ defiance is small, but dangerous. Even using magic privately is a risk.

  • Mirah fears that Arana will one day show signs of magic—and then they will have no way to hide.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Arana experiences wonder for the first time. Though she is too young to grasp its significance, she has taken the first step toward magic.

  • Aelius reaffirms his belief that magic should not be erased. This belief will later cost him dearly.

  • Mirah’s anxiety grows—she knows Aelius is right, but she also knows they cannot afford to be caught.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • Arana’s first exposure to magic is through her father’s stories.

  • Aelius believes magic is something to be shared, not hidden.

  • Mirah is the cautious one, knowing their survival depends on secrecy.

Ending Scene Visual (Final Moments of the Scene)

  • The last spark fades, but Arana keeps staring at the air where it had been, as if she can still see it.

  • Aelius tucks her into bed, but as he steps away, her tiny voice whispers, “Tell me another one?”

  • He laughs, but there is sadness in it. There will not always be more stories.

Questions for Refinement

  1. Do you want to expand on the specific story Aelius tells—perhaps hinting at lost history that Arana will later uncover?

  2. Should Arana unknowingly react to the magic in some way, a subtle hint that she will one day wield it herself?

  3. Would you like Mirah to pull Aelius aside after the story, warning him more seriously about the dangers of being discovered?

These scenes give a powerful emotional core before tragedy strikes later. Let me know what refinements you’d like before moving forward.

Scene 4: The Weight of Suppression

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Lower District of Sovalis
Time of Day: Late Morning
Time of Year: Summer, Fram Month
Weather: The air is warm but slightly humid, the scent of rain lingering from the night before
POV Character: Mirah
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few days

Scene Summary

Mirah watches Aelius as he sketches at the kitchen table, the charcoal stick trembling slightly between his fingers. He rubs at his temples now and then, the way he always does when a headache lingers. His other hand rests idly on the wooden surface, fingers twitching every so often, as if reaching for something unseen.

She has noticed these signs before—the side effects of suppressing his magic too long.

Aelius always tries to hide it. If she had not spent years watching him closely, she might not have noticed. But she does. The slight tension in his jaw, the way his breathing sometimes goes shallow when he forces himself to stillness. She remembers the stories of magicians who lost themselves to exhaustion, their magic turned inward, strangling them from within.

She says nothing at first, simply setting down a cup of tea beside him. Aelius glances up, eyes tired, but he smiles.

“You’re worrying again,” he says, teasing.

She sits across from him, studying his face. “I don’t like seeing you like this.”

His smile doesn’t fade, but it falters. “It’ll pass.”

“Will it?”

Aelius looks down at his hands, flexing them, as if testing for control. “I have to be careful. That’s all.”

Mirah exhales slowly. “You need to let it out. Just a little.”

His fingers tighten around the cup. “Not here. Not anymore.”

They sit in silence for a long moment. The city outside hums with life, but inside their home, there is only quiet, the unspoken truth hanging between them.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Establishes the side effects of suppressing magic—tremors, headaches, tension.

  • Reinforces the risks of exposure—Aelius refuses to release even a small amount of magic, knowing it’s too dangerous.

  • Foreshadows later events—if he keeps suppressing it too long, it will take a toll.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Aelius is too proud or too afraid to release his magic, despite the strain.

  • Mirah is caught between fear for his safety and fear of being discovered.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Mirah’s worry grows. She sees what this is doing to him, but there is nothing she can do.

  • Aelius becomes more withdrawn, more careful.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • Magic, when suppressed for too long, harms the wielder.

  • Aelius knows this but still refuses to risk exposure.

Ending Scene Visual

  • Aelius rubs at his temples again, staring down at his work, the charcoal in his hand trembling.

  • Mirah watches, pressing her hands together in her lap, resisting the urge to reach for him.

  • The air between them is warm but heavy, like the silence before a storm.

Scene 5: A Dangerous Slip

Location: The Market Square, Sovalis
Time of Day: Afternoon
Time of Year: Summer, Fram Month
Weather: A bright day, the air thick with heat
POV Character: Mirah
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A day or two

Scene Summary

The market is bustling, the scent of fresh bread mixing with the brine of fish stands, the laughter of children rising above the merchants’ calls. Mirah clasps Arana’s small hand, weaving through the crowd, exchanging quiet greetings with familiar vendors.

At the heart of the market, a fountain glistens under the summer sun, water catching the light in flickering patterns. Arana tugs at her hand, pointing excitedly.

“Look, Mama!” she exclaims. “It looks like the dancing lights at home!”

Mirah’s breath catches.

For a moment, she cannot move, cannot think. The words crash through her like an icy wave. She glances around, heart hammering, scanning the faces around them—did anyone hear?

Arana doesn’t notice her mother’s sudden stillness. She giggles, reaching toward the water, delighting in the way it sparkles. Completely unaware of the danger in her words.

Mirah forces herself to stay calm. She kneels, brushing a strand of hair behind Arana’s ear, voice light but firm. “We should get home now, little one. Before the bread gets cold.”

Arana pouts but nods, slipping her hand back into her mother’s as they walk away. Mirah’s grip is tighter now, her steps quicker.

The warmth of the sun does little to chase away the chill settling in her bones.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • The first genuine risk of discovery—Arana unintentionally references magic in public.

  • Mirah realizes how easy it would be for a child’s innocence to expose them.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Mirah must stay composed, even as fear grips her.

  • Arana is too young to understand why her words are dangerous.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Mirah is shaken. She has kept her fears contained, but now they are real.

  • Arana is still innocent, but this moment plants a seed in her mother’s mind—how will they ever keep her safe if she keeps noticing things?

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • Magic has left an impression on Arana, even if she doesn’t understand it yet.

Ending Scene Visual

  • Mirah walking faster than before, her hold on Arana’s hand a little too tight.

  • Arana glancing back toward the fountain, confused by her mother’s sudden worry.

  • The city buzzing around them, unaware of the moment that nearly changed everything.

Scene 6: The Lesson

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Sovalis
Time of Day: Night
Time of Year: Summer, Fram Month
Weather: The air is thick with the heat of the day, the night bringing little relief
POV Character: Mirah

Scene Summary

The house is quiet, except for the slow creak of a rocking chair. Arana sits on her mother’s lap, drowsy but awake, her small fingers curled against the fabric of Mirah’s dress.

Mirah strokes her daughter’s hair, waiting, choosing her words carefully.

“Little one,” she says softly, “do you remember what you said today, about the lights?”

Arana nods against her shoulder. “They were pretty.”

Mirah closes her eyes briefly, then shifts, holding Arana so she can look into her daughter’s sleepy face. “Yes, they were. But there are things we don’t talk about when we’re outside. Things we keep just for us.”

Arana frowns, confused. “Why?”

Mirah hesitates. How does one explain something so cruel to a child?

“Because some people don’t understand,” she finally says. “And when people don’t understand something, they can be afraid of it.”

Arana’s frown deepens. “But Papa’s stories aren’t scary.”

Mirah’s throat tightens. “No. But we must still keep them to ourselves, alright?”

Arana is quiet for a moment, then nods. “Okay, Mama.”

Mirah presses a kiss to her forehead. “Good girl.”

She tucks Arana into bed, lingering a moment, watching her daughter drift to sleep.

There is no relief, only the weight of knowing that one day, this warning may not be enough.

  • Aelius standing in the doorway, watching silently.

Scene 7: Whispers of Escape

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Sovalis
Time of Day: Early Afternoon
Time of Year: Late Summer, Fram Month

POV Character: Mirah (with Arana eavesdropping)

Scene Summary

The house smells of steeping tea and fresh bread, though the tension in the kitchen makes the warmth of the home feel colder. Moren sits at the table, his fingers wrapped around a cup, but he hasn’t taken a sip. His coat is dusted with travel, his boots still damp with the mud of Sovalis’ streets.

Across from him, Aelius and Mirah speak in hushed voices, their conversation careful, heavy. The topic is one they’ve avoided for weeks—should they leave the city before it’s too late?

“Moren, any word from the north? We’ve been thinking about heading that way...”

Moren, who had just been holding his cup without drinking, sets it down too hard, tea sloshing over his fingers. “Sorry,” he mumbles, wiping his hands on his trousers. He looks weary, his eyes shadowed. “I wouldn’t. Not now. It’s bad up there, Aelius. Really bad. The Wittshires tried last spring, remember? They’ve...” His voice trails off, and he swallows hard. “They didn’t make it. All of them, gone. Even the little one.”

Mirah gasps, covering her mouth with a trembling hand. “That’s horrific. To think they didn’t even spare the child...”

Aelius looks down, his jaw tightening. He had already heard rumors in the city today—of another family, another set of arrests. The noose is tightening.

Moren exhales, rubbing a hand down his face. “Someone must have talked.”

Mirah shudders, wrapping her arms around herself. “So nowhere is safe.”

Aelius’ voice is grim. “Not unless we find people who can be trusted.”

They speak of allies, of whether fleeing is still an option, if it ever was. But Moren doesn’t have good news. The King has given the Church free reign, and the Order of Flame has only tightened its grip. Wild Magicians are being hunted with more precision than ever before.

The conversation darkens, turns bitter. Aelius grows cynical, shaking his head at the futility of it all. Mirah, however, turns quiet—not bitter, but afraid.

The kitchen falls silent.

Upstairs, where she had been giggling and playing with Jona, Arana has gone still. She has crept to the staircase, listening. She doesn’t understand much, but the voices are different. Not like when her father tells stories, not like when her mother hums while stirring soup. The laughter is gone, and the bitterness in the voices below sinks into her, even if she cannot name it.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Aelius and Mirah seriously consider leaving Sovalis, but Moren warns them it’s too dangerous.

  • The Wittshire family’s fate foreshadows what is coming.

  • The Order of Flame is becoming more organized, suggesting someone is giving them information.

  • Moren urges caution—nowhere is safe, but careful alliances might help.

  • Arana overhears, planting the first seed of unease in her young mind.

  • Fear of betrayal—someone is giving names to the Order.

  • Arana overhears, too young to understand but old enough to feel the weight of it.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Aelius becomes more bitter, convinced there’s no way out.

  • Mirah becomes more anxious, realizing they cannot keep ignoring the danger.

  • Arana experiences fear for the first time, though she does not yet understand why.

Later, as dusk settles and Moren readies to leave, he lingers at the door, speaking quietly to Aelius and Mirah.

“Keep your eyes open. Stay safe. I’ll check in soon.”

Arana, hugging the puppy to her chest, waves to Moren. She doesn’t know why, but she doesn’t want him to leave. The heaviness in the air lingers.

That night, as Mirah tucks Arana into bed, her embrace is tighter than usual, protective. Her lips press against her daughter’s forehead, whispering, “Sleep well, my Little Star.” Her voice is thick, as if she is trying to shield her child from the weight of what remains unsaid.

Arana falls asleep with her mother’s warmth around her, but outside, the city’s shadows stretch longer than before.

Scene 8: The Knock at the Door

Location: Moren’s Home, Sovalis, Lower City
Time of Day: Late Night
Time of Year: Late Summer, Fram Month
Weather: The city is quiet, the air thick with humidity, a distant storm looming
POV Character: Moren
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

Scene Summary

Moren sat at his small kitchen table, fingers wrapped around a cup of warm tea, its steam curling softly in the dim light of the room. He had just returned from Aelius and Mirah’s home, his mind filled with thoughts of how to get them out before it was too late.

His hands ached, not from the journey but from the weight of his own helplessness. He had met with members of the resistance just last week, a scattered network of those still fighting against the Church’s growing tyranny. If he could connect Aelius and Mirah with them, maybe they’d have a chance. Maybe little Arana wouldn’t end up like so many others—alone, hunted. Like his own daughter.

The thought was a wound that never closed.

Then came the knock.

A sequence of heavy thuds, too forceful, too deliberate. The sound sent ice down Moren’s spine.

He had heard that knock before.

Three years ago. The night his daughter was taken.

The tea cup clattered from his hands, spilling across the worn wood of the table as he stood, heart hammering against his ribs.

The door burst open before he could take a step.

Armed men flooded into the room, clad in dark city watch uniforms, the insignia of the Order of Flame stitched onto their shoulders.

Moren barely had time to raise his hands before they were on him.

A heavy hand seized his arm, twisting it behind his back. Another yanked him forward, forcing him onto his knees. The rough fibers of a rope burned against his wrists as they bound him fast.

“You have no right!” Moren growled, struggling against their grip. His voice was steady, but his pulse was a wild drumbeat in his ears.

The leader of the group stepped forward, his face unreadable, his voice cold and methodical. “Recent amendments to the law of our King now make it a crime to withhold information regarding the whereabouts of known magicians.”

He unrolled a parchment, reading with crisp efficiency.

“You, Moren Thumber, have associated closely with the convicted witches Lila and Siva Thumber, and are hereby arrested for aiding and abetting in their crimes.”

Moren’s breath caught. Lila and Siva. His wife. His daughter.

His anger surged, but he knew better than to fight. Against two guards in full armor, he had no chance. He clenched his teeth as they dragged him toward the door.

His house—his home—blurred in his vision as they hauled him away. He knew he would never see it again.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Moren is arrested under new laws targeting anyone associated with Wild Magicians.

  • The Order of Flame is escalating its persecution, tightening its grip over the city.

  • The king’s decree is being weaponized against even those with distant connections to magic.

  • Moren’s knowledge of Aelius and Mirah’s magic puts them at greater risk.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Moren is arrested without trial or evidence, only the vague accusation of association.

  • His attempt to protect Aelius and Mirah is cut short.

  • The city remains silent—no one will speak against the guards.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Moren loses what little safety he had left. He is now a direct target of the Church.

  • His fate foreshadows what will happen to Aelius and Mirah if they do not escape.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • The Order of Flame is becoming more efficient—someone is informing them.

  • The people of Sovalis have become too afraid to resist.

Ending Scene Visual

  • The city is dark, but curtains shift in nearby houses, shadows watching but never interfering.

  • The guards march Moren through the streets, their armor clinking against the stone.

  • He does not look back.

Scene 9: The Holding Cell

Location: Holding Facility, Sovalis
Time of Day: Early Morning
Time of Year: Late Summer, Fram Month
Weather: A restless wind stirs outside, the air thick with the promise of rain
POV Character: Moren
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

Scene Summary

The cell was small, cold, and smelled of damp stone.

Moren sat on the rough wooden bench, wrists still aching from the ropes. Across from him, three other prisoners stared in quiet resignation. He had never seen them before, but he already knew why they were here.

“Association with convicted magicians?” he muttered, rubbing his raw wrists.

They all nodded.

Beside one of the prisoners—a young woman—a child no older than six clung to her arm, his small face pale with fear.

Moren exhaled slowly, anger simmering just beneath his exhaustion. “This is madness.” He looked toward the iron-barred door, toward the laughter of the guards drinking in the next room. They were celebrating another successful haul.

He shook his head, voice low. “They don’t even think anymore. Just follow orders. As if they’re not even human anymore.”

No one answered.

The night stretched long, marked only by the quiet sobs of the little boy. Moren couldn’t sleep, couldn’t close his eyes. He stared at the ceiling, at the cracks in the stone, at the dark beyond the bars.

He had lost everything before. He had rebuilt, as much as he could.

And now it was happening again.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • The Church’s persecution extends beyond Wild Magicians, now targeting entire families.

  • Moren’s imprisonment shows that those who speak against the Church disappear.

  • The guards have become desensitized, treating arrests like routine work.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Moren cannot fight back—any resistance would mean death.

  • His arrest means he cannot warn Aelius and Mirah.

  • Even children are being taken.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Moren loses hope—until he sees the child. It reminds him why he must survive.

  • His anger shifts to determination—he cannot let this cycle continue.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • The guards take joy in their power—arrests are no longer about justice, only control.

  • Even innocent people are being taken—fear is spreading.

Ending Scene Visual

  • The child stirs in his sleep, face pressed into his mother’s sleeve.

  • Outside, the guards drink and laugh, uncaring.

  • Moren’s fists clench—this will not be the end of his story.

Scene 10: The Carriage Ride to the Unknown

Location: Leaving Sovalis, toward the labor camps
Time of Day: Sunrise
Time of Year: Late Summer, Fram Month
Weather: The sky is tinged with red, the air thick with oncoming rain
POV Character: Moren
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

Scene Summary

At dawn, the guards returned. They yanked Moren and the others to their feet, binding their wrists once more.

“Line up! Time to move.”

The group was led outside, where a horse-drawn carriage with a tarp-covered back waited.

They were shoved inside.

Moren felt the shift of the road beneath them, the rattle of wooden wheels against cobblestone. Through the gaps in the tarp, he caught glimpses of the city moving past. He counted the turns, feeling the direction change.

North.

He knew where they were going.

The boy beside him sniffled, muffling his cries in his mother’s sleeve.

Moren exhaled, staring at the dim light filtering through the canvas.

He was not afraid to die. But he would not let it end like this.

ChapterTitle: Reports of a Kingdom Under Watch
ChapterText:
Scene Summary

King Alistair sat at the head of the ornate council table, his gaze steady but lined with fatigue. The heavy air of the chamber was thick with the scent of ink, wax, and old parchment as the meeting commenced. His kingdom was more secure than ever, yet the weight of his decisions sat heavier still.

The first to speak was High Inquisitor Varick, his voice smooth, practiced, filled with the satisfaction of a man who saw his work coming to fruition.

“Your Majesty, the measures you implemented four years ago today are bearing fruit,” he began, his expression sharp with pride. “The Order of Flame now firmly controls the public discourse, ensuring loyalty and orthodoxy as planned. Checkpoints secure our towns and villages, safeguarding them against the corruption of illicit magic.”

His words carried the tone of an orchestrator of fate, confident in his dominion over not just laws, but the very thoughts of the people.

“Random inspections and loyalty oaths have significantly strengthened our position, ensuring that all citizens live in accordance with the Church’s teachings,” he continued. “Our actions are a testament to our resolve to protect the realm from the chaos of dissent and heresy.”

Alistair said nothing, only nodding. He had given the Order of Flame the power they desired, yet in doing so, he had relinquished something in return. The Church’s reach now touched every corner of his kingdom, and he was no longer certain whether he led them, or they led him.

The advisor on cultural control rose next.

“Public burnings of troubling books have purified homes and libraries, eradicating dangerous ideas that once threatened to mislead your people. The once-common healers, now recognized as practitioners of dark arts, have been rightfully accused and removed from our communities. These actions have reinforced the moral and spiritual purity of Veridian.”

Burnings. Erasures. Vanishing knowledge.

Alistair clenched his jaw but gave no outward sign of his unease. It had to be done. These were the necessary prices for unity.

The judicial advisor stepped forward.

“The integration of the Church’s authority with the royal legal system has been seamless, Your Majesty. Minor disputes are now adjudicated under the watchful eyes of clerical councils, which judiciously apply divine law. This has significantly reduced petty squabbles and instilled a profound respect for divine order throughout the kingdom.”

A perfect system, they called it. But Alistair was not so certain.

The advisor on land and farming spoke last, addressing the natural disasters that continued to plague the land.

“The increase in natural calamities, from floods to earthquakes, clearly demonstrates the desperate backlash of magicians against our efforts. These events, while challenging, only affirm the necessity of our actions. These divine messages have rallied our people, strengthening their faith and their resolve to stand with us against the darkness.”

Alistair’s fingers curled slightly against the armrest of his chair.

How convenient that every failure of nature could be pinned upon their enemies.

The reports continued, each advisor speaking of the hard-won victories for stability and divine order. Alistair listened, his expression unreadable, his silence masking the storm of thoughts within him.

When the last voice fell silent, he straightened slightly.

“These reports affirm our path,” he stated, his voice carrying across the chamber. “We must continue to guard against the heretics and infidels with unwavering resolve. My kingdom’s future, my son’s kingdom’s future, depends on the sanctity and security we uphold today.”

A chorus of affirmations followed.

Yet as the council dispersed, Alistair remained seated. He stared down at the wax seal on the parchment before him, stamped with the insignia of the Order of Flame.

For all the security they had achieved, why did his kingdom still feel so fragile?

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Veridian has fully transformed into a theocracy. The Church now controls not only faith but law, education, medicine, and public discourse.

  • The Order of Flame has reached peak authority. Their checkpoints, oaths, and public purges are now seen as normal.

  • Natural disasters are worsening, but the Church frames them as proof of their righteousness.

  • King Alistair has secured his throne—but has he lost control to the Church?

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Alistair’s growing doubt. He does not regret enforcing order, but he fears what it is becoming.

  • The Order of Flame is not just a tool— it is a force that may be slipping beyond his control.

  • The kingdom may be more “secure,” but the tension has not lifted—only deepened.

How This Scene Changes the King

  • He begins resolute, confident in his reign.

  • By the end, a seed of doubt lingers. His kingdom is strong, yet he does not feel at ease.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • The people are more devout, but out of fear, not faith.

  • The destruction of knowledge is systematic—history itself is being rewritten.

  • Alistair realizes, perhaps too late, that the Church does not need him as much as he once believed.

Ending Scene Visual

  • The council chamber empties, but the king remains seated.

  • The wax seal on the parchment feels heavier than it should.

  • The faint sound of thunder in the distance.

Questions for Refinement

  1. Would you like to introduce a single dissenting voice within the council, a noble or advisor hesitant about the Church’s growing control?

  2. Should there be more explicit signs of the king’s doubt, or should it remain subtle for now?

  3. Would you like an external event to interrupt the meeting, perhaps news of an escaped magician or an unexpected rebellion?

Scene Summary

The morning air inside their small home was cold, but familiar. The fireplace had burned down to embers overnight, the room wrapped in a dim, golden haze. Arana sat at the kitchen table, watching her father intently.

She had seen him do this before—every morning, for as long as she could remember.

Aelius knelt by the hearth, hands hovering over the fresh logs, his brow drawn in that way that meant he was thinking hard.

“Concentrate… just a bit more,” he murmured, his fingers shifting in slow, grasping motions.

Arana crossed her fingers under the table. It was a little game she played with herself—if she wished hard enough, maybe today would be one of the good days.

A flicker.

The embers glowed brighter, a spark catching the dry kindling.

Arana grinned as tiny flames licked at the logs—but just as quickly, something went wrong.

A sharp crack split the air as one of the thicker logs snapped in half, splintering in an unnatural way. The fire shuddered, hissed—then died completely, as if startled into silence.

The sudden darkness felt deafening.

“Damn it!”

Aelius’ voice cut through the quiet, sharp and raw. His hand slammed down against the mantle, the dull thud making Arana flinch.

For a moment, the room was colder—not just from the lack of fire, but from something else. Something she didn’t have words for.

She shrunk into herself, gripping the edges of her chair, the warmth of her excitement gone.

“Papa?” she whispered, hesitant.

Aelius turned sharply at her voice, his expression still shadowed with frustration—until he saw her. The moment he did, his face crumpled, regret washing through him like a tide.

He knelt in front of her, hands settling on her small shoulders, his voice soft again.

“I’m sorry, Arana,” he said quickly, his thumb brushing against the fabric of her sleeve. “I didn’t mean to frighten you.”

Arana didn’t move, still watching him warily.

Aelius sighed, his grip gentle. “Sometimes, it just doesn’t do what it’s supposed to.” He let out a small, humorless laugh. “Nobody ever taught me how to use it properly, you know that. The magic didn’t work, and I got upset. Can you forgive me?”

She hesitated for only a moment, then nodded. “It’s okay, Papa. Can we bring the fire back?”

Aelius’ smile didn’t quite reach his eyes, but he nodded. “Of course we can.”

This time, when he raised his hand, the fire relit itself effortlessly, as though nothing had ever been wrong.

The room was warm again, full of flickering light and crackling heat.

But Arana noticed things more now.

The quiet whispers in the kitchen at night when they thought she was asleep.
The way her mother’s face tightened whenever her father struggled with magic.
The way stress made it harder for him to control.

She didn’t understand everything, but she understood enough.

The world outside their home was getting scarier. And it was starting to seep into their walls.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • First direct moment where Arana senses something is deeply wrong.

  • Aelius’ frustration hints at the worsening strain of suppressing magic.

  • The family’s tension is increasing—Arana notices things she didn’t before.

  • Foreshadows the future—Aelius’ struggle with control will only worsen.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Aelius’ magic is slipping, and it is affecting his emotions.

  • Arana is beginning to sense that something is wrong, but she doesn’t fully understand it.

  • Mirah’s concern is growing, but she stays silent for now.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Aelius’ guilt deepens. He realizes how much his struggles are affecting his daughter.

  • Arana begins noticing more about her parents’ fear.

  • The family’s stability is slowly fraying.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • Stress affects magic, making it harder to control.

  • Aelius has never been properly trained—his power is instinctual, but unstable.

  • Arana senses change, but does not yet understand what it means.

Ending Scene Visual

  • The fire crackles warmly once more, but the warmth does not fully return.

  • Aelius watches the flames longer than he needs to, lost in thought.

  • Arana, still curled in her chair, stares at the flickering logs, something uneasy settling in her small chest.

Questions for Refinement

  1. Would you like to add Mirah’s reaction after this moment, perhaps showing her more visibly worried?

  2. Should Aelius attempt to explain more to Arana, or leave her in innocent confusion for now?

  3. Do you want to hint at Arana’s first internal questioning of magic—why it is so secret, why it feels dangerous?

 

Scene 3: A Mother’s Work

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Sovalis
Time of Day: Late Afternoon
Time of Year: Autumn, Gila Month
Weather: A soft, steady drizzle outside, filling the air with the scent of damp earth
POV Character: Arana (child’s perspective)
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few days

Scene Summary

Arana sat near the hearth, watching the rhythmic motion of her mother’s hands at the sewing machine. The needle dipped and rose, a quiet clicking sound filling the space as Mirah guided the fabric beneath her fingers with precision. It was mesmerizing.

Arana had always thought her mother’s sewing was more than just skill. The clothes she made never tore easily, the seams never came undone. Even when the other children in the neighborhood wore patches on their sleeves, Arana’s own dresses stayed whole, as if the fabric had been stitched with something stronger than thread.

Was it magic?

She knew better than to ask.

“Keep breathing, then,” her father would tease sometimes when he watched Mirah work, suggesting that her very breath must be weaving the fabric together.

Arana had started watching for it—the little moments where her mother’s fingers lingered over a stitch, the subtle shift in the air. The way the cloth seemed to settle, as if responding to her mother’s touch.

But Mirah’s magic was not like her father’s. There were no sparks, no sudden bursts of fire. Her mother’s magic was quiet, hidden—woven into the ordinary.

More than that, her mother’s magic was careful.

Observations from a Child’s Eyes

Arana didn’t remember when it had started, exactly. The way her mother seemed to avoid taking her to the market anymore.

She missed those trips—the colors, the voices, the sticky sweetness of candied nuts sold at the corner stall. But she did not miss the way her mother’s hand would grip hers too tightly, fingers tense around her wrist, her eyes darting constantly, watching the crowd.

Now, her mother always found a neighbor to watch her instead. The market had become something too dangerous, too unpredictable.

Even now, sitting at the table, Arana could see it.

Her mother’s hands never trembled. Her stitches never faltered. But there was something in the way her shoulders carried a tension that never fully faded.

Fear. Not the sharp kind that came with sudden danger—the slow, suffocating kind. The kind that settled into your bones and never quite left.

An Evening of Lightness

The smell of freshly baked pie filled the kitchen as the sky outside darkened, the rain tapering off into mist. The table was warm, filled with the quiet clinking of utensils, the murmurs of laughter.

“Did everything stay calm in the kitchen today? No runaway fires?” Mirah asked, nudging Aelius playfully.

Arana giggled, stealing a glance at her father. Earlier that day, he had burned one of his sketches—a tiny, misdirected spark from his quill scorching the edges of the paper.

“No fires today, Mama,” she reassured, grinning. “And Papa promised to start teaching me how to draw!”

“That’s right,” Aelius said, smiling warmly at her. “We’ll begin with simple lines and shapes. And your mother will make sure we have sturdy aprons—just in case we get a little too artistic.”

Mirah raised a playful brow. “Absolutely. I’ll make sure they’re as fireproof as possible.”

Laughter rippled through the room, the weight of their world lifting for a moment.

Arana sat with her notebook open, her small fingers clutching a piece of charcoal. She mimicked her father’s posture—leaning slightly forward, brow furrowed in deep concentration, completely lost in her little world of lines and shapes.

Aelius caught Mirah’s gaze across the table, a silent exchange passing between them.

“We’re doing alright, aren’t we?” he murmured.

“We are,” Mirah whispered back, watching Arana with something tender, something fiercely protective in her eyes.

Outside, the city was growing colder, more dangerous.

But inside their home, they had this.

For now.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points

  • Mirah’s magic is subtle, woven into ordinary things, not explosive like Aelius’.

  • Arana begins noticing her mother’s fear more clearly—small things she hadn’t understood before.

  • The family finds brief moments of joy, but their world is growing smaller.

Conflicts & Obstacles

  • Mirah avoids taking Arana to public places.

  • Arana does not fully understand the reason, but she feels the shift.

  • Despite the warmth of their home, the tension of the outside world lingers beneath the surface.

How This Scene Changes the Characters

  • Arana’s awareness grows. She is still young, but she is beginning to see the way fear shapes her parents’ lives.

  • Mirah’s burden becomes more visible—she carries her fear differently than Aelius, but it is no less present.

  • Aelius, despite his frustration with magic, still cherishes these small family moments.

High Moment / Key Info Revealed

  • Magic, when hidden, can become part of the everyday—but it is never truly gone.

  • Mirah is doing everything she can to protect Arana, but the walls are closing in.

Ending Scene Visual

  • Arana doodling in her notebook, tongue sticking out in deep focus.

  • Aelius watching her with quiet amusement, his own sketch unfinished beside him.

  • Mirah, hands folded in her lap, holding onto this moment as long as she can.

Questions for Refinement

  1. Would you like a stronger hint that Mirah is using magic in her sewing—perhaps a moment where Arana swears she sees the thread shimmer?

  2. Should we add a moment where Arana realizes she misses something about the market trips, reinforcing the shift in their world?

  3. Do you want Mirah to share a story about how she learned to sew, offering Arana a brief insight into her past?

 

Scene 4: Secrets and Fears

Location: Aelius and Mirah’s Home, Sovalis
Time of Day: Late Night
Time of Year: Autumn, Gila Month
Weather: The air outside is still, heavy with the tension of an approaching storm
POV Character: Aelius and Mirah (with Arana overhearing)
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: One night

Scene Summary

The house had settled into the hush of the late hours. Arana had been tucked into bed, her small form curled beneath the blankets, safe for now.

In the dim glow of the single candle that flickered between them, Aelius and Mirah sat at their kitchen table, their voices hushed, yet heavy with words they had spoken too many times before.

Mirah sighed, rubbing tired hands over her face. “I saw Kara today,” she said finally, her voice low. “When I was out with Arana to buy bread. Her husband was taken last week.”

Aelius tensed, fingers tightening around his cup. He had already heard the rumors. But hearing them confirmed sent a cold thread of unease through him.

“Jora too,” he muttered. “I still can’t believe it.” He let out a sharp breath, shaking his head. “Those Inquisitors… twisting magic into a weapon to hunt us. Calling it righteous. Calling it divine.”

Mirah let out a humorless laugh. “They call it divine magic now, sanctioned by the church. Nothing wicked about it in their minds.” Her lips curled in disdain. “As if magic chooses its bearers based on men’s decrees.”

Aelius exhaled through his nose, his jaw tight. “They’re coming closer, Mirah.” His voice was quieter now, heavier. “Every whispered spell, every minor charm could be a noose around our necks. And just as every spell held back is.”

Mirah reached across the table, her fingers finding his, a warm contrast to the cold fear settling in his bones.

“We need to be more cautious,” he said. “Especially around Arana. She’s still so young, so unaware of what this means.”

Mirah’s grip tightened slightly. “We’ve taught her to keep our magic a secret, but she doesn’t understand why yet.”

She paused, staring down at the wood grain of the table. “She might not even have it, Aelius. She might have been spared.”

Aelius let out a quiet, bitter chuckle. “You know that’s unlikely.”

Mirah swallowed, her throat tight. She did know. They would find out in a few years—when Arana turned ten. When magic, if it lived within her, would begin to surface.

And then what?

Aelius’ voice was quiet. “If she does have it… we might need to leave. Find somewhere safer.”

Mirah sighed. “Perhaps. But where?” She shook her head. “The Order is reaching beyond the cities. There are rumors of villages being purged. Even the countryside isn’t safe anymore.”

Aelius stared into his cup, expression dark. “I don’t even know if I want to know more.”

Silence stretched between them, filled only by the distant drip-drip of water from the eaves outside.

Then, Mirah murmured, “Allies can be dangerous, Aelius. Trusting the wrong person could end everything for us.”

Aelius nodded slowly. “But hiding might no longer be enough.”

Unseen Eyes, Unheard Questions

Arana lay awake in bed.

She had heard the shift in their voices, the way her mother’s tone dipped lower, the way her father’s replies had turned clipped and tense.

Curious and uneasy, she had slipped out of bed, pressing herself to the top of the stairs, small and unseen in the darkness.

The words floated up to her, too complex to fully grasp—persecution, wicked magic, Inquisitors.

But she understood enough.

Magic was not just a secret. It was something dangerous. Not like hiding a toy or a trinket, but something much, much bigger.

Her mother’s fear.
Her father’s frustration.
The way they spoke of people being taken, of people disappearing.

Her tiny fingers gripped the wood of the railing, her heartbeat quickening.

She had always known magic was something they did not speak of.

But now, for the first time, she wondered… if it was something they should fear.

She crept back to bed, slipping under the covers, but sleep did not come.

The night felt bigger, heavier.

And the shadows seemed darker than before.

Back in the Kitchen

Aelius rubbed a hand down his face, exhaustion creeping in, but sleep was a luxury neither of them could afford.

“We need to start reaching out,” he said finally. “Find others. If things get worse…”

Mirah closed her eyes briefly, then nodded. “We will. Carefully.”

The candle burned lower, its flame dancing in the stillness.

For tonight, they were safe.

But for how long?

The palace gardens had been transformed into a vision of color and celebration. Banners of royal blue and gold fluttered from the trellises, and garlands of autumn flowers wound around every archway. The scent of roasted nuts and honey cakes filled the air as noble guests arrived in their finest attire. It was Prince Edric’s sixth birthday, and the kingdom had gathered to celebrate.

Young Edric stood at the heart of it all, dressed in a finely embroidered tunic, his golden curls gleaming in the sunlight. He greeted the lords and ladies with polite nods, just as he had been taught. But despite the grandeur around him, his attention kept slipping elsewhere.

A butterfly—a brilliant blue flash among the flower beds—drifted past him. Without hesitation, Edric darted after it, weaving between the nobles with the ease of a child who had never known restraint.

Lady Tharston, a noblewoman with an opulent hat, chuckled. “The young prince certainly looks the part today.”

“Indeed,” her husband agreed, watching Edric twirl beneath the falling leaves, his laughter unburdened, unspoiled. “He carries the hopes of Veridian with such ease.”

A few steps away, a visiting dignitary observed the scene, his gaze thoughtful. “Look at him—completely unaware of what he will become.” He sighed. “It is in these small moments that we remember the purity of youth, before the weight of crowns dulls the light in their eyes.”

Another courtier, a duchess from Brama, murmured “He has his mother’s spirit.”

“Yes,” Sir Gellantara replied. “And let’s hope he inherits her wisdom, too. He’ll need it, given what lies ahead.”

Edric’s Bond with Animals

Edric was a prince, but more often than not, his companions were not other noble children but the creatures that roamed the palace grounds.

He sought the quiet places—the hidden nooks of the garden, the still corners of the orchards where the birds gathered, the kennels where the palace hounds lay.

After the formalities of cake, songs, and speeches—none of which he truly understood—Edric slipped away from the main festivities, seeking something more familiar. He removed his fine shoes, stepping onto the cool grass, and wandered toward the hound enclosures.

The guards who followed him at a respectful distance exchanged amused glances, knowing his habits well.

As he approached, the hounds—usually disciplined and reserved—perked up instantly. Their tails wagged, their ears pricked forward, and one by one, they pressed against the gates, whining softly.

The moment Edric touched the latch, the hounds burst free.

Rather than scatter, they circled him, tails wagging, playful but gentle. The onlookers chuckled at the sight, nobles commenting on how charming the young prince looked amidst the creatures that adored him.

“He’s always been fond of them,” one guest remarked. “No doubt he sneaks them treats from the kitchens.”

Another laughed. “It’s no wonder the animals adore him—he treats them as friends, not servants.”

Even the birds seemed to take notice.

A small sparrow fluttered down, landing lightly on Edric’s shoulder. Then another. And another. The prince giggled in delight, tilting his head as if listening to their delicate songs.

“The birds probably think he’s part of the garden itself,” someone mused.

To Edric, this was simply how things were. He had never known a world where animals did not trust him, where creatures did not respond to his presence with ease.

The Day’s End

As the sun dipped lower, painting the sky in hues of amber and violet, the celebration wound down. The guests lingered over their last cups of wine, watching as Edric lay in the grass, surrounded by the hounds, his eyes fixed on the sky.

His father was inside, speaking with his council. His future was being discussed, decisions being made. But Edric did not think of that.

For now, he only thought of the rustling leaves, the warmth of the hounds at his side, and the feeling of belonging—not to a crown, but to something simpler.

King Alistair stood beneath the stone arch of the secluded pavilion, watching the last remnants of his son’s birthday celebration unfold.

Beyond the meticulously kept palace lawns, lanterns flickered to life, casting pools of golden light across the gathering dusk. The final notes of music drifted into silence, and the laughter of nobles and courtiers softened as guests slowly took their leave.

Yet here in the garden, Prince Edric still played.

Two servants chased after him in a mock game, pretending he was too quick for them, their laughter ringing through the cooling air. Edric’s giggles, pure and unburdened, thrilled over to his father, an echo of childhood untouched by the weight of duty.

Alistair’s composed expression softened, if only for a moment.

“May he always find such happiness,” he murmured to himself, his voice barely more than a whisper. A rare, fleeting smile crossed his face. His son delighted in the simple things, and it filled his heart with something both warm and aching.

For all the grandeur of today’s celebrations, it was these moments that Alistair would remember.

Edric was still untouched by the realities of power, by the responsibilities that came with being heir to the throne. Alistair envied him for that.

The boy was young now, but the world would not wait forever.

The Burden of a King

Alistair exhaled slowly, the moment of warmth fading as duty pressed its weight upon his shoulders once more.

He remembered his own youth—the shift from boy to man to king.

It had come too quickly, and it had been unkind.

One day, Edric would face the same path. He would have to balance this innocence with the weight of the crown. A child who ran barefoot through the grass could not remain so forever.

His son had his mother’s spirit.

That was both a blessing and a danger.

Edric was warm. He was open. He cared too easily—for people, for creatures, for the world around him.

That would make him beloved.

It would also make him vulnerable.

Alistair knew the hard edges of kingship. He had learned them through war, through loss, through the necessity of wielding power with a steady hand. He had hardened himself, for the sake of his people, for the sake of his throne.

Would Edric be able to do the same?

Would he learn the cost of mercy before it cost him everything?

Alistair turned away from the garden, stepping back into the shadows of the palace.

The warmth of the evening, the softness of his son’s laughter, faded behind him.

The night was setting in, and with it, the kingdom demanded his attention once more.

His resolve was clear.

He would shape Edric into the king he needed to be—not a boy who played in the gardens, but a ruler who would hold Veridian together.

For love was not enough to hold a kingdom.

Strength, foresight, and sacrifice—those were the foundations of kings.

Scene 1: An Unseen Moment

Location: The streets of Sovalis, bustling market district
Time of Day: Late morning, the sun bright but not yet at its peak
Time of Year: Autumn, Heno Month
Weather: Clear skies, the scent of fresh bread and spices thick in the air
POV Character: Arana (Age 5)
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few weeks

The market buzzed around her—voices sharp with haggling, laughter spilling from a nearby stall, the steady clatter of cart wheels over uneven cobblestones. The air smelled like roasted nuts and fresh bread, and Arana breathed it in, eyes darting between bright fabrics and baskets of glossy fruit.

It had been so long since she’d been allowed to come along. She wasn’t going to waste it.

Her father walked ahead, a bundle of wrapped supplies tucked under one arm, his eyes always moving. Watching. Her mother’s hand was firm in hers, not too tight, but enough to keep her close.

There was too much to see.

She lagged half a step behind, trying to get a better look at a cluster of brightly colored ribbons hanging from a stall. The wind tugged at them, making them flutter like little birds caught in a net. She wanted to stop, just for a moment—

Someone slammed into her shoulder.

She barely had time to yelp before the world tipped, and then she was falling, scraping against the rough stone. A sharp sting tore up her hands and knees, and she sucked in a breath—

A shadow moved over her.

“Hey,” her father’s voice cut through the noise, cold and sharp. “Watch where you’re going.”

Arana looked up. The man who had knocked into her barely spared her a glance. He was big, bigger than her father, with thick arms and a stained tunic, the scent of sweat and fish clinging to him like a second skin.

“Not my problem,” the man muttered, already turning away.

Her father took a step forward.

Mirah’s grip on Arana tightened.

“Let it go,” she said softly, tugging him back.

Aelius didn’t move.

The man scoffed. “Control your brat,” he said, shaking his head like they weren’t worth his time.

The space between them turned hot.

Not like the midday sun. Not like the warm breeze rolling in from the docks.

A flicker of heat.

The scent of something just starting to burn.

The man stumbled back with a startled grunt, his boots scraping against the stone. He patted at his tunic, his face scrunching in confusion like he thought a coal had jumped from a brazier onto his chest.

Mirah’s fingers dug into Aelius’s wrist.

“Aelius,” she whispered, urgent and firm.

His jaw was tight, his breath shallow. Arana could see his fingers twitch, just slightly, before he curled them into a fist. The warmth in the air faded, but it left something uneasy in its wake.

The man shot him a glare but didn’t linger, muttering under his breath as he turned and disappeared into the crowd.

Arana’s mother let out a breath like she’d been holding it too long. Then she laughed, quick and airy, like she could shake it all off. “Gods, people are so rude these days,” she said, kneeling to dust off Arana’s scraped palms. “We should send a petition. Mandatory etiquette lessons at the docks.”

Her voice was light, teasing, but her hands were shaking just a little.

Arana didn’t move, didn’t speak.

She had seen something.

Felt something.

The heat. The way the air had changed.

The way her father had looked—how his shoulders had gone rigid, how his fingers had curled.

Aelius didn’t laugh.

“Let’s go,” he said, voice tight.

He pulled Arana to her feet, turned, and walked. Mirah took Arana’s hand again, her grip still gentle, but this time it felt different.

The market noise swallowed them whole again, folding around them like nothing had happened.

But Arana kept stealing glances at her father’s back as they walked.

The Weight of Something Unspoken

The three of them walked quickly, too quickly for it to be normal. Mirah kept talking, voice light, filling the space with small things—“Should’ve bought those peaches,” “Hope the butcher still has good cuts left,” “You alright, love? You took a nasty fall.”

Arana nodded when she was supposed to. Answered when she was supposed to.

But she felt something twisting inside her.

She had seen something.

Something that shouldn’t have happened.

She wanted to ask. To say something. But the way her father walked, stiff and silent, kept the words locked in her throat.

She looked down at her scraped palms, flexing her fingers.

Her mother gave her hand a squeeze, but Arana barely felt it.

Her father had told her before—never in front of people. Never where someone might see.

Her heart beat a little faster.

They had seen.

Hadn’t they?

No shouts had followed. No cries of alarm.

The city had swallowed it whole, the way it swallowed everything.

But something about the way her father hadn’t looked at her since made her stomach feel heavy.

Ending Scene Visuals:

  • Aelius walking ahead, his posture stiff, his knuckles white around the bundle of supplies.

  • Mirah smiling, talking like nothing had happened, but her grip on Arana’s hand still a little too tight.

  • Arana staring at her scraped palms, the lingering warmth still fresh in her memory.

  • The crowded market swallowing them up again, the noise and movement pressing in around them like a shield.

What This Scene Accomplishes:

Shifts focus to Arana’s perspective as a five-year-old—she doesn’t fully understand what happened, but she knows it was wrong.
Mirah trying to de-escalate with humor and small talk—she doesn’t want to make it a bigger moment, but the tension is still there.
Hints at Arana feeling uneasy, but never outright stating guilt—the weight is left lingering in her chest, not forced onto the reader.
Keeps Aelius silent, reinforcing the tension without explanation.
