Scene 6: The Lantern Quarter – The City’s Stage

Location: The Lantern Quarter, the heart of Sovalis’ entertainment
Time of Day: Late evening, the sky deep blue, the first stars emerging
Time of Year: Early autumn, the wind cool but not yet biting
Weather: Crisp air carries the scent of roasting meat, spiced wine, and perfume
POV Character: Arana
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few days

Arana had never been here before.

The Lantern Quarter was unlike anything she had imagined. She had heard stories, of course—stories whispered in market stalls and over cheap drinks in the docks. A place of laughter and excess, of music and sin, of masked strangers and gilded lies. But hearing about it and seeing it were two different things.

Lanterns in shades of deep crimson, gold, and violet hung from rooftops and swayed in the evening breeze, bathing the streets in warm, flickering color. The glow reflected off polished stones, off the elaborate signs of music halls and theaters, off the painted faces of performers.

Music spilled from open doorways, blending together in an intoxicating mess of sounds—the steady pulse of drums, the weeping of violins, the slow, lazy strum of a lute. In one tavern, a man with silvered hair recited a poem to an enraptured crowd. In another, dancers twirled in half-sheer silks, laughter and clinking glasses punctuating the melody of flutes.

This was not the world Arana knew.

She tensed, wary, glancing at Grizz. He walked forward at a slow, steady pace, a man who had been here before and had no fear of it. Liam, by contrast, was grinning like a fool, his sharp eyes darting between the performers, the crowds, the food stalls with sizzling meat skewers and candied nuts.

“This,” Liam announced, “is my new favorite place in the whole godsdamned city.”

Arana scowled. “It smells like perfume and bad choices.”

Liam cackled. “Exactly.”

Grizz sighed but didn’t comment. He led them deeper into the Lantern Quarter, navigating the maze of winding streets that pulsed with energy, each turn revealing something new. A man dressed in royal colors played a harp with expert precision. Across the street, an old woman with tattoos covering her arms told a story in a language Arana didn’t recognize, her words punctuated with the occasional gasp of her audience.

There were writers, scholars, poets, actors. And then, there were the brothels.

Some, bright and extravagant, with names like The Velvet Garden and The House of Delights, had wealthy patrons draped in silks and laughter. Others, smaller, dimmer, looked more like a last resort.

“Stay out of those,” Grizz muttered. He didn’t need to say which ones.

They passed a man in priestly robes, his face red, the front of his cassock wrinkled and hastily re-tied. He muttered something under his breath and hurried in the opposite direction.

Arana smirked. “Priests aren’t supposed to be here, right?”

Grizz snorted. “Priests aren’t supposed to do a lot of things.”

Arana felt a sick sense of satisfaction at that. The Church talked about purity, about devotion, about casting out the unworthy—yet their own slipped into sin-soaked alleyways, paying to forget.

Then, they turned a corner.

And she saw the real reason the Lantern Quarter felt wrong.

Forget-Me-Not.

The blue haze of it curled out of a long pipe, held in delicate fingers, a woman exhaling smoke with a vacant, glassy stare. The smell was sweet, like honey and dried flowers, but Arana had learned that the prettier something smelled, the nastier it often was, especially when it came to people.

Two men sat in the alley, their hands trembling, their eyes hollowed, the faint, unnatural grin of the Smiling Rot clinging to their slack faces.

They weren’t dead.

But they were gone.

Grizz grabbed her shoulder, steering her away before she could stop and stare. “Don’t get too close,” he muttered.

“I wasn’t going to,” Arana snapped, but her voice felt thin.

She had heard the stories. But seeing it—seeing the forgetting, the slow unraveling of a person before they even died—that was different.

Liam was quiet. For once.

When they finally left the Lantern Quarter behind, Arana released a breath she hadn’t realized she was holding.

She wasn’t sure she wanted to come back.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • Arana is introduced to the Lantern Quarter, a place of wealth, art, and pleasure, but also of corruption.

  • She sees the Church’s hypocrisy firsthand, watching a priest slip from a brothel.

  • Forget-Me-Not is more than just a street problem. It is here, in the places where the rich and powerful play.

  • Grizz warns her away from the drug, reinforcing its danger.

  • Liam is fascinated by the excess and freedom of the district. Arana is unsettled by it.

Scene 7: Gutter’s End – The Poor Districts of Sovalis

Location: The slums of Sovalis, both the southern and northwestern districts
Time of Day: Late afternoon, the sky overcast, the light fading
Time of Year: Early autumn, the air thick with smoke from cooking fires
Weather: Damp, with a storm rolling in from the west
POV Character: Arana

“This,” Grizz said, “is where the city forgets people.”

The southern slums were familiar—cramped, dirty, loud. But they weren’t hopeless. People still worked, still bartered, still held onto their dignity and hopes for the future.

This was where Arana had spent her whole life.

She had slept under those roofs, stolen from those market stalls, hidden in those alleyways. The houses were small, patched with scrap wood and stolen bricks, but families lived here. People shared what little they had.

But the northwestern slum?

That was different.

As they crossed the bridge over the Jarun, the stench hit first. The river carried the city’s filth along these streets, a slow-moving sludge that turned the air sour. The buildings were more ruins than homes, sagging under their own weight.

There was no real market here. Just a few stalls, selling half-rotten food, spoiled meat, old scraps. The people here didn’t just struggle.

They starved.

The few figures that lingered in the alleys were gaunt, their faces hollow, their clothes hanging from their frames.

Arana had never seen a place like this.

Grizz walked ahead, unmoved. “Most people don’t come here,” he said. “Not unless they have to.”

Liam looked uneasy. “Why are we here, then?”

Grizz didn’t answer right away. Instead, he pointed at a crumbling structure near the river.

A church.

Not the grand, shining cathedrals from the center of Sovalis. This one was small, battered, barely holding together. But it had people lining up for food.

Clerics stood at the doors, handing out stale bread and thin soup. The people took it without looking them in the eye.

The Church didn’t hunt people here.

It kept them quiet.

“Why feed them if they don’t care about them?” Arana asked.

Grizz gave her a long, slow look.

“Because starving people riot,” he said. “People with just enough? They don’t.”

The answer sank into her like a stone.

This wasn’t kindness.
It was control.

She looked around again, taking in the sick, the hungry, the forgotten.

No one here had names.

And if they died, no one would notice.

Liam cleared his throat. “So, uh. Can we go now?”

Arana nodded.

She had seen enough.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • Arana learns there are two types of poverty. One where people still fight to live, and one where they are already lost.

  • The Church feeds the starving not out of kindness, but to keep them weak and dependent.

  • Arana understands now that survival isn’t just about food or shelter—it’s about not letting the city erase you.

  • The northwestern slums show what could happen to her if she ever lost her grip.

ChapterTitle: A Prince’s Autumn (Edric’s Isolation Deepens in Sheen)
ChapterText:
The grand dining hall stretched wider than necessary, its long table polished to a dull sheen. The fire in the hearth burned low, its warmth swallowed by the vastness of the chamber. Despite the golden light of the chandeliers, the mountain stone always felt cool beneath his fingertips when he traced the carved edges of the table.

Edric sat alone, as he often did.

His father’s chair remained empty for now, but the place was set. That meant he was coming. Not every night, but some nights.

The servant moved quietly as he placed down a fresh cut of venison and a bowl of root vegetables. The scent of cloves and rosemary mixed with the woodsmoke, familiar, steady. The palace ran on routine, on discipline.

Edric picked up his knife and fork, cutting precisely as he had been taught. No wasted movement, no unnecessary mess. His father always said that a man who could not control his own hands had no business ruling others.

A door opened at the far end of the hall, and his father entered.

King Alistair moved with purpose, his fur-lined cloak trailing slightly behind him. His presence always changed a room. Even in the quiet, Edric could feel the shift, the air seeming to tighten as the servants straightened, as the warmth of the fire felt a little stronger.

“Edric.” His voice carried easily, though it held no sharpness. He was not displeased.

“Father,” Edric greeted, setting down his utensils as the king took his seat.

The servants moved like clockwork, bringing new dishes—roasted game, black bread, thick cuts of cheese. Alistair did not immediately reach for his food. Instead, he took a slow look around the room, his gaze passing over the empty seats.

“You eat well?” he asked, finally settling his eyes on Edric.

“Yes,” Edric answered.

His father gave a small nod, then picked up his own knife.

They ate in the quiet for a while. Not uncomfortable silence, just expectant.

Alistair was a man of presence, a man who did not speak unless the words meant something. There was no idle chatter with him, no unnecessary softness, but there was always intention.

After a few minutes, he finally spoke.

“What did you learn today?”

Edric straightened slightly. He knew the answer was not just about what he had been taught, but what he had taken from it.

“I had lessons on the history of Veridian and the laws regarding the rights of trade between dominions,” he answered carefully. “Master Callas says understanding them will prevent disputes.”

His father gave a small, approving nod. “And do you think that’s true?”

Edric hesitated. He thought about the ledgers, the disputes, the careful agreements he had been shown.

“I think laws do not stop people from wanting more than they are given,” he said after a moment.

A pause.

Then, his father let out a quiet chuckle. “Good. You are learning.”

Edric felt something settle inside him. Not warmth exactly, but something steady. Something solid.

His father did not waste praise.

But when he gave it, he meant it.

Refinement Questions:

  1. Do you want Alistair to show a bit more warmth? Maybe a hand on Edric’s shoulder, or a more direct show of pride?

  2. Should Edric push further with his thoughts? Or is his restraint part of his character development?

  3. Do you want a contrast with his past lessons? Perhaps hinting at how he used to struggle with these questions, but has grown into them?

Scene 2: The Weight of a Kingdom

(The father behind the crown, and the child behind the heir.)

Location: The King’s Study, Mountain Palace of Sheen
Time of Day: Late evening, the oil lamps casting golden halos of light
Time of Year: Early autumn, the cold creeping in through the mountain passes
Weather: A quiet drizzle against the windows, the scent of damp stone and parchment in the air
POV Character: Edric (Age 8)

The study was one of Edric’s favorite places in the palace.

It was warm, lined with shelves of books and maps, the fire always burning low in the hearth. His father’s heavy desk sat at the far end of the room, covered in neatly arranged parchment and thick-bound ledgers, the scent of ink and candle wax lingering in the air.

His father sat behind the desk now, quill scratching against paper. The only sound in the room was the occasional crackle of the fire and the distant tapping of rain against the windows.

Edric, however, was not quiet.

“…and the brown dog, the big one with the torn ear—he’s the fastest, I swear it! Even faster than the black one. He ran all the way from the kennels to the lower gate before I even made it halfway!”

His father gave a small, distracted hum, still focused on the paper in front of him.

Encouraged, Edric kept going. “Master Rellen says the dogs are trained for hunting, but I think they listen to me better. Maybe because I bring them scraps when the cooks aren’t looking.” He grinned, proud of himself. “I want to go hunting soon. Proper hunting. Not just running in the fields pretending.”

Still, no response.

Edric trailed off, watching his father’s face. The candlelight flickered over his furrowed brow, deepening the lines of focus and fatigue. His father always carried the weight of the crown, but tonight, it seemed heavier.

He hesitated, then softly asked, “Father… what’s wrong?”

The quill stilled.

His father exhaled slowly, setting the pen aside. He rubbed a hand over his temple before meeting Edric’s gaze.

“There have been more reports,” Alistair said at last.

Edric straightened slightly. “From the Order?”

His father shook his head. “From all over Veridian.”

He leaned back in his chair, his voice steady but heavy. “Spring floods came too strong, drowning crops before they could take root. The summer heat followed, drying what little remained. Villages struggle to feed themselves. In the north, an earthquake collapsed part of the fjord, blocking the main trade route. The merchants in the cities feel it first, but soon it will reach the villages. The people.”

Edric frowned, trying to grasp the weight of those words.

“Can’t they… move the rocks… with magic?” he asked hesitantly.

His father drew in a sharp breath.

Every mention of magic made his father’s expression darken. Even from him.

“That is what the Wild magicians do,” his father said firmly. There was no anger in his voice, but there was something worse, worry. “That is what the Wild Magicians did. Their heresy makes the gods angry son. What we do is pray to the gods. And our Divine magicians tell them what to do. If we are devout enough, the gods will help. You should know that by now, Edric. You are a future king. You have to learn. To know.”

He shook his head, exhaling slowly. “Either way, it will take time. And in the meantime, people are suffering.”

Edric sat with that for a moment. His fingers curled slightly in his lap.

“Okay, then we pray more. Make the gods smite!” He thumps his little fist on the desk, making a barely audible thud.

His father smiled at him then. A real smile. But it was tinged with something else—something sad.

Then, after a moment, he let out a slow breath and shook his head. “I forget sometimes.”

Edric tilted his head. “Forget what?”

His father sighed. “That you are still just a child.”

The words unsettled him.

His father’s voice was not sharp, not scolding, but… regretful.

“Am not!” Edric proclaimed, bold as only a small boy could be.

Alistair chuckled at that.

“You should be worrying about the dogs and the hunts, not failed harvests and trade routes,” he said, shaking his head. “I’m sorry, Edric. For burdening you so early with these things. You shouldn’t have to think of such matters, but I need you to know about them.”

Edric sat up straighter. “I am old enough to know things! Like that Brenna is in love with Jude from the kitchens—and that Varick is a stiff prick.”

His father burst out laughing.

Edric grinned, delighted by the reaction.

“A stiff prick, is he? And where have you heard that, son?”

Edric hesitated, then mimicked the roundabout hand gesture he had seen the adults use. “Around.”

His father let out another chuckle, shaking his head. “Well… they’re not wrong.”

The warmth of that moment lingered between them, stretching like a thin golden thread.

But then his father’s expression turned serious again.

“One day,” he said, “I won’t be here anymore, Edric. And you will have to make choices for all the people of Veridian.” He exhaled, his eyes flickering with something Edric couldn’t name. “I need them to be good choices. The right choices. Choices that help us defeat the Wild magicians forever, so we can all be safe and happy.”

Edric swallowed.

His father had spoken of ‘one day’ before. But this time, it didn’t feel like something far away.

It felt… close.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • Edric’s growing awareness of the burdens of rulership.

  • Alistair’s exhaustion—his fear that time is running out, that Veridian is still vulnerable.

  • A glimpse of warmth in their relationship—Alistair is still a father, not just a king.

  • Edric’s belief in the gods is still pure, but his father’s faith seems weighed down by doubt.

  • The mention of magic immediately darkens Alistair’s mood, reinforcing his fear of its presence.

  • Hints of Varick’s reputation, which will be relevant later.

Ending Scene Visual:

  • Edric’s bold grin fading into something quieter as his father’s words settle.

  • The fire crackling in the hearth, its warmth not quite reaching the growing weight in the room.

  • Alistair watching his son, measuring the boy who would one day take his place.

Refinement Questions:

  1. Do you want Alistair to soften further at the end, or should the tension linger?

  2. Would you like Edric to ask more questions, pressing about ‘one day’ and what it really means?

  3. Should we hint at more specific events that have Alistair so concerned—something beyond the natural disasters?

 

Scene 3: Shadows of the Future

(Alistair’s worry deepens, the weight of the crown pressing heavier than ever.)

Location: The King’s Study, Mountain Palace of Sheen
Time of Day: Late night, the candles burning low
Time of Year: Early autumn, the winds howling against the mountain walls
Weather: A rising storm outside, rain tapping against the windowpanes
POV Character: King Alistair

The storm had begun to swell outside, wind pressing against the stone walls of the palace like a living thing, rattling the heavy wooden shutters. The mountain air was cold and biting, even here, in the sanctuary of the royal study. The candles flickered low, their golden light dancing along the edges of the room’s dark wood and scattered parchment.

Alistair poured himself a measure of black brandy and set the bottle aside with a dull thud. He hadn’t touched it in months. Tonight, though… tonight, his thoughts were darker than usual.

Across the desk, Varick sat in the same chair he always did when he called him to his study. His face was unreadable as ever, the flickering light making his deep-set eyes seem even more shadowed. His eyes were uncomfortably unblinking, his lips thin and tight, his hands folded neatly atop his lap. There was something in his stillness, that always made Alistair a little uneasy, stiff like a prick, Alistar felt a chuckle rising, despite his bitter mood.

He did not speak right away.

He turned the heavy ring on his finger, a habit when his mind wandered too far into dark territory.

When he finally broke the silence, his voice was quieter than he meant it to be. “He spoke of magic again.”

Varick did not react outwardly. He rarely did.

The High Inquisitor simply tilted his head ever so slightly, watching the king with measured patience. “A dangerous habit. But the boy is young, Your Majesty. Children speak of many things.”

Alistair exhaled slowly. “It’s more than that.”

He leaned forward, pressing his fingertips against his temple. “He dreams of it. He… wonders about it.” The last word was spoken with an almost bitter edge. “He should know better by now. He knows what the Wild magicians have done. And yet—he still asks.”

Varick’s fingers curled slightly into each other, but his voice remained smooth. “And what would you have me do?”

Alistair scoffed, shaking his head. “Nothing. Not yet.” He took a sip of brandy, letting the burn settle deep in his chest. “He is just a boy. But that will not be true forever.”

Varick said nothing. He let the weight of the words settle.

Varick inclined his head. “Of course.” A pause. Then, voice smooth as silk, he added, “Though, if you wish for a more… lasting lesson, there are ways.”

Alistair narrowed his eyes. “Speak plainly.”

Varick’s lips curled ever so slightly. Not a smile. Something colder.

“A demonstration,” he said, voice smooth. “A controlled setting. A chance for the prince to see truth with his own eyes, before his mind is clouded by sentimental nonsense.

Alistair stiffened. He felt where this was going, but he let Varick continue.

“The inquisitors have captured three heretics in the past month. One a woman, two men. Each sworn to the false gods, each caught in acts of treasonous magic.” Varick’s fingers drummed lightly against the chair’s armrest. “One of them claims innocence. Naturally.”

Alistair felt his grip tighten around the base of his glass.

“Imagine the lesson,” Varick continued. “The prince, watching with his own eyes what Wild magic truly is. No fairy tales, no gilded illusions, no childish wondering. Just truth.”

His voice dropped, his words slow and deliberate.

“A heretic pleading their innocence, forced to sit and wait, trembling fingers, a coward, pressed just enough until they reach for their power, their own instincts betraying them. And the moment it happens—” He exhaled, his fingers tightening slightly, as if savoring the thought.

“Enough...” his voice was low and raw.

The inquisitor did not blink. “Or,” he said almost excitedly, as though he had not been interrupted, “we simply let them sit. A few days without release, and they begin to tremble. Another few days, and the convulsions begin. The shivering, the dizziness, the hallucinations.”

His tone did not change, but there was something dark beneath it, something almost reverent.

“If the boy watches them long enough, you know…” He waved his hand almost casually.

Alistair did know. He had seen it firsthand. Had ordered it himself, executions, purges. And yet, he had never thought of it this way. This felt personal.

“Enough.” he repeated, the word dripping from between his lips.

Varick continued, untouched by the king’s intervention. “Or, if you wish for something swifter, we simply provoke them.” He spread his hands slightly. “Pain is a simple trigger. The instinct to survive always wins in the end. I could do it myself if your majesty wants me to.”

A smile barely noticeably curled the edges of his lips.

Alistair stood abruptly, his chair scraping loudly against the stone. “Enough!”

Varick stopped. His lips pressed together tightly trying to suppress that thin smile that was just tugging at him, though his eyes remained cold.

Alistair gripped the edge of the desk, forcing himself to steady his breath.

“He is eight years old, Varick.”

“A child who will one day rule a kingdom,” Varick countered, voice patient. “A child who will face enemies far crueler than a mere demonstration. A child who will have to give orders just like this himself. If he does not learn now, what a weak King he will be.”

Alistair clenched his fists.

Varick remained seated, perfectly composed, as though they were discussing the logistics of a trade route instead of ending a boy’s childhood.

The king turned away from him, staring out the rain-streaked window, his reflection a dark silhouette against the glass.

“You are not to bring this to him,” Alistair said, voice low and firm. “You will not speak of it, not to my son, not to anyone.”

Varick inclined his head slightly. “As you command, Your Majesty.”

A silence stretched between them, heavy and unspoken.

Then, Alistair turned from the window, his voice quieter now.

“But soon,” he murmured, more to himself than to Varick, “he will have to learn.”

Varick said nothing.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • Varick reveals his methods for exposing Wild magic. He enjoys the process, relishes the breaking of heretics, and hopes the Church might grant him a Talisman to enhance his work.

  • Alistair is appalled. Though he has ordered countless inquisitions, he is shaken by Varick’s personal enjoyment of cruelty.

  • Foreshadowing: Despite his horror, Alistair begins to accept that his son cannot be shielded forever.

  • Varick plants a seed. Alistair refuses now, but one day, he may not have the strength to stop it.

Ending Scene Visual:

  • Alistair standing at the rain-streaked window, his own reflection looking back at him.

  • Varick, still seated, his shadow stretching long in the candlelight.

  • The storm outside growing louder, as if the gods themselves were whispering warnings in the wind.

Refinement Questions:

  1. Should Varick push even further before Alistair stops him?

  2. Would you like to show more of Alistair’s internal struggle—perhaps flashes of his own experiences with Wild magic?

  3. Does Alistair fully reject Varick here, or does part of him already know he will need him?

POV Character: Edric (Age 8)
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

Edric sat curled beneath the heavy blankets of his bed, but he did not sleep. His fingers gripped the edge of the fabric, his knuckles white as he stared at the ceiling. The stone was smooth, darkened by shadows from the dim candle on his bedside table. He could hear the soft patter of rain outside, the faint crackle of the dying hearth. The storm was over, but something still churned inside him.

His father’s words lingered.

Their heresy makes the gods angry, son.

The gods. He had never thought about them being angry before. He had only ever thought of them as golden figures in the stained-glass windows of the cathedral, as the warm light that poured over the priests when they spoke of the divine. His father had told him before that the gods protected Veridian. But tonight, it had sounded different.

The gods were angry.

And Wild magicians were the cause.

He swallowed hard. He had always thought of Wild magicians as a distant thing—like the villains in the stories his tutors told him, the ones who were always defeated by noble knights and righteous kings. But the way his father spoke…

It wasn’t a story.

It was real.

A tightening feeling curled in his stomach. He sat up slowly, the heavy blankets pooling around his waist, the cold air biting at his skin. His gaze flicked to the tall arched window. The rain had slowed to a whisper, mist swirling over the darkened mountains beyond the glass.

He imagined, for the first time, Wild magicians moving through that mist.

Would they come here?

Could they?

A shiver crawled down his spine, and he shook his head sharply, pushing the thought away. No. The Order of Flame protected them. The inquisitors hunted them down. His father was the greatest king Veridian had ever known.

But then another thought surfaced—one he didn’t like.

What if the Wild magicians didn’t just live in the mountains? What if they were in the villages? The cities? Hidden, waiting, pretending to be ordinary people? His father had said that some of them looked normal, that they lied, that they pretended to be harmless.

A twisting unease made his skin crawl.

What if he had seen one before and hadn’t even known?

Wrapping his arms wrapped tightly around his knees, Edric buried his face against them. No matter how much he tried to push them away, the thoughts kept circling, creeping in like whispers through the cracks in the stone.

The floods and earthquakes were because of them?
People were starving because of them?
What if the gods were angry at him, too, because he had thought magic was… fun?

A tightness coiled in his chest, the weight of it pressing down until it was hard to breathe.

Was that why the gods let his mother die?

A sharp inhale. His breath hitched, unsteady. That thought had never come before.

The priests always said his mother had been called to the gods, that her death had been part of their divine plan. But what if it hadn’t?

What if it had been the Wild magicians?
What if magic had stolen her from him before he was even born?

His heartbeat thundered in his ears, each beat like a hammer against his ribs. The room, once warm with candlelight, felt suddenly cold.

Squeezing his eyes shut, he willed the thoughts away.

He wanted to go to his father, to hear that everything was alright, that Veridian was safe, that he was safe. Sitting beside him, listening to his steady voice, just knowing he was there, would make the fear fade.

But that was what a child would do.

Am not! He had told his father that only hours ago. He had meant it.

A shuddering breath left him. He would not act like a child now.

Instead, he slid off the bed, bare feet touching the cold stone floor. The sharp chill grounded him, but it did not ease the unease curling in his stomach. Kneeling beside the bedside table, he clasped his hands together, bowed his head, and whispered the words he had been taught.

But for the first time in his life, he did not pray because he had been told to.

He prayed because he was afraid.

Story Advancement & Key Plot Points:

  • Edric begins to truly fear Wild magic. The idea of it being a story in his head fades, and reality begins to take hold.

  • For the first time, he questions his mother’s death. He had always accepted it as something beyond his understanding, but the idea that magic might have played a role plants a dark seed.

  • His faith is strengthened—not out of devotion, but out of fear. He turns to the gods not with innocence, but with the first flicker of desperation.

  • His trust in his father deepens, but his worldview narrows. He begins to see magic not as a concept, but as a real and immediate threat.

Ending Scene Visuals:

  • Edric kneeling in the dim candlelight, his small hands clasped tightly in prayer.

  • The flickering glow casting long shadows across the walls.

  • The rain misting over the dark mountains beyond the window.

  • The faint whisper of wind against the glass, almost like a breath.

 

 

Scene 6: The Last Days of Childhood

(The weight of responsibility settles, as a boy turns closer to a king.)

Location: Mountain Palace of Sheen, Edric’s Chamber → The King’s Study

Time of Day: Early evening, the sun slipping behind the peaks

Time of Year: Late Autumn, one week before Irrst Month (Edric’s birthday)

Weather: Crisp and clear, the first signs of winter in the wind

POV Character: King Alistair

Time Passed Since Previous Scene: Two months

The boy had changed.

Alistair had seen it before in men—never in a child.

Two months ago, Edric had bounded into this study with the boundless energy of youth, talking of magic like it was a game. Now, as he watched from his chair, he saw the difference in every movement his son made. The way he carried himself, the way he measured his words before speaking. Even now, across the room, Edric sat at the edge of his bed, polishing the silver clasp of his riding cloak with slow, methodical strokes.

He used to fidget. He used to hum under his breath when he was alone, distracted by whatever half-formed thought ran through his young mind. Now, he simply sat, back straight, eyes focused.

A week from now, he would turn nine years old. A boy still. But one who had learned fear.

Alistair should have felt satisfaction in that. It was what he wanted. What he needed. A king could not be soft. And yet, watching his son like this, he felt the unfamiliar ache of regret settling somewhere deep inside him.

“Your Majesty?”

Alistair turned at the soft voice of Brenna, standing in the doorway. His son’s nursemaid had been with him since birth, and her loyalty was never in question. She had never once challenged him before. Yet, tonight, there was something in her eyes that made his jaw tighten.

“Edric is in your study, sire.” A pause. Then, softer, “I think you should speak with him.”

Alistair studied her for a moment.

She never told him what to do.

Without another word, he stood and walked past her, down the candlelit halls of the mountain palace.

The Study – A King and His Son

When Alistair entered the dimly lit study, he found Edric sitting at his usual place, a book open in front of him. But he wasn’t reading.

He was staring at the candle in front of him, the small flame flickering as if it, too, felt the weight of the silence.

Alistair let the heavy doors close behind him.

“You are quiet tonight,” he observed.

Edric’s fingers tightened slightly on the edge of the book. He nodded, but did not speak.

Alistair exhaled, moving to the chair across from him. He let the silence stretch between them, waiting to see if Edric would break it first.

Finally, after a long pause, the boy spoke.

“Will the gods help this year?”

The words were soft, but heavy.

Alistair’s stomach tightened.

“Why do you ask?”

Edric shifted slightly, his small hands tightening into fists in his lap. “Because I prayed, and the floods did not stop.”

The air in the room grew heavier.

Alistair leaned forward, resting his forearms on the table. “The gods listen. But they do not always answer in ways we understand.”

Edric looked up at him then, eyes far too old for a child.

“What if they don’t answer at all?”

Alistair let out a slow breath. He could not let his son slip into doubt, not now. Not ever.

“Then we make them listen.”

The boy’s expression did not change, but something flickered behind his eyes.

Alistair recognized it.

It was the first ember of something sharp and unyielding. Not childish stubbornness. Not a tantrum.

Resolve.

And yet… his son was still so young.

Alistair reached out, resting a hand on Edric’s shoulder. “You have done well.”

Edric straightened under the touch, but said nothing.

Alistair felt the warmth of his son’s small frame beneath his palm, and something inside him clenched. He had wanted this. A son who understood. A son who saw the world as it was, who did not fill his head with nonsense and dreams.

But gods, he had wanted more time.

“You will be a great king,” Alistair murmured, squeezing his shoulder once before drawing back.

Edric looked at him for a long moment.

Then, softly, “I hope so.”

The words should not have unsettled him.

But they did.

Ending Scene Visuals:

  • Edric sitting alone in the flickering candlelight, his face calm but his hands tight against his lap.

  • Alistair standing in the doorway, watching his son, knowing the child in him was fading too soon.

  • The mountain wind howling outside, cold and relentless.

What This Scene Accomplishes:

  1. Shows how Edric has changed – his childhood fading into something heavier.

  2. Deepens the relationship between him and his father – Alistair now truly sees his son as a future king, not just a boy.

  3. Hints at future conflict – Edric’s first true doubts about the gods, and Alistair’s fear that he is growing up too fast.

  4. Leads perfectly into Arana’s scene – the soft, slow-burning fear in Edric clashing violently with the visceral brutality of Arana’s world.

Scene 7: The Boundaries of a Prince

(A father’s growing fear, a tutor’s creeping influence.)

Location: The King’s Study, Mountain Palace of Sheen

Time of Day: Late night, the storm whispering at the mountain’s edges

Time of Year: Late Autumn, one week before Irrst Month (Edric’s birthday)

Weather: A bitter wind slamming against the windowpanes, the first true cold creeping through the mountain halls

POV Character: King Alistair

Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

A low gust of wind howled outside, rattling the mountain palace as if something was trying to claw its way in. The heavy wooden shutters creaked against the force of it, but the stone walls of the study remained unmoved.

Inside, the chamber was dimly lit, suffused with the scent of ink and old parchment. The fire had burned low, the orange embers casting flickering shadows along the polished wood of the desk.

King Alistair stood behind it, his arms crossed, his shoulders squared. His presence alone was enough to fill the space with unspoken weight. He did not sit. He did not pour himself a drink. He did not need the trappings of contemplation to know what had to be done.

Varick sat in the chair opposite, composed as ever, hands folded neatly in his lap, posture unerringly still. He did not fidget, did not shift. He simply watched.

Alistair let the silence stretch, let the storm outside fill the space where words had not yet been spoken. Then, finally, his voice came low and measured:

“You have been teaching my son.”

Varick inclined his head. “As you commanded, Your Majesty.”

A pause.

Alistair’s fingers curled slightly at his sides. “And what, exactly, have you been teaching him?”

Varick blinked once. “The lessons befitting a future king. Politics, history, trade.”

“And?”

The inquisitor tilted his head ever so slightly, something unreadable flickering in his dark eyes.

“Truths,” he said simply.

Alistair’s jaw tensed. He had expected this answer. He had feared it.

“I told you to teach him, not mold him in your own image.”

Varick did not react, did not shrink beneath the accusation. If anything, his lips curled faintly, not quite a smile, something colder.

“Your Majesty,” he said smoothly, “I have done only what was necessary.”

Alistair leaned forward, bracing his hands against the desk. The candlelight cast deep shadows across his face.

“You do not decide what is necessary for my son.”

Varick’s expression did not change. “And yet, you have hesitated. You tell him of dangers, but shield him from seeing them. You speak of power, yet refuse to let him witness its cost.”

The king’s grip tightened against the wood. He hated that Varick spoke as though he were the only one who understood the burden of kingship.

Varick continued, unbothered. “Your son must be prepared. The world will not be kind to him.”

Alistair straightened, voice dangerously low. “And you believe I do not know that?”

Varick’s gaze did not waver.

“I have shown him the places where Wild magicians and the Divine have clashed,” he admitted. “Where families have been burned alive in their homes. Where children have been left orphaned in the streets, all because of their heresy.” He leaned back slightly, his tone almost contemplative. “You have told him stories. I have shown him what they left behind.”

A cold weight settled in Alistair’s chest.

He should have been furious. But the anger was dulled by something worse—resignation.

Edric had changed. He had grown quieter, more serious. His boyish wonder had been chipped away too quickly. It was exactly what Alistair had wanted.

So why did he feel as though he had lost something precious?

Silence stretched between them.

Finally, Alistair exhaled, slow and controlled. “He is not to leave the palace grounds.”

Varick did not react, as if he had already foreseen this outcome. “Of course, Your Majesty.”

Alistair straightened, his eyes like flint. “And no more of your stories.”

A pause.

Then, finally, Varick inclined his head. “If that is your wish.”

Alistair studied him for a moment longer, searching for any trace of defiance. But the inquisitor remained as unreadable as ever.

Still, Alistair knew—this was not the end of it.

Ending Scene Visuals:

  • The king standing at the window, watching the rain streak down the glass, his reflection cold and distant.

  • Varick’s silhouette framed by the firelight, unmoving, unreadable.

  • The doors closing between them with a quiet but final click.

What This Scene Accomplishes:

  1. Confirms Alistair’s fears—Edric’s rapid change wasn’t just natural growth; Varick accelerated it.

  2. Creates a turning point—Edric is confined to the palace grounds, marking a shift in his freedoms.

  3. Strengthens the theme of inevitability—Alistair wanted to shield his son, but the world is forcing his hand.

  4. Further cements Varick’s influence—he remains patient, calculated, and always a step ahead.

Refinement Questions:

  1. Would you like more insight into Alistair’s emotions here? Should his inner thoughts betray more of his regret, or should he remain guarded?

  2. Does Varick’s dialogue feel appropriately manipulative, or should he push harder?

  3. Would you like a more direct consequence for Varick’s actions—perhaps Alistair considering replacing him, but knowing he won’t?

  4. Should there be a moment of warmth for Alistair before the end of the scene? Or is the focus on his growing detachment from Edric the right choice?

Scene 8: The Prince’s Ninth Name Day

(Opulence, defiance, and the shadow of fear—before the light of joy breaks through.)

Location: The Courtyards and Grand Hall of Sheen Palace

Time of Day: Morning to Early Afternoon

Time of Year: Irrst Month, early winter creeping in

Weather: Crisp, cold air under a bright blue sky; snow dusting the peaks of the Pharr Mountains

POV Character: Edric (Age 9)

Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few weeks

A Morning of Celebration

The palace had never been so alive.

The courtyards of Sheen Palace bustled with laughter, music, and the scent of roasting meats drifting on the cold morning air. The nobles of Veridian had arrived in their finest silks and furs, their children running about in the fresh snowfall, cheeks flushed pink. The noble sons of powerful families, close to Edric’s age, had been invited to compete in games—archery contests, horse races, and tests of wit and memory.

Edric had won more than half of them.

He was the prince, after all.

He had spent the morning running, laughing, wrestling in the snow, and throwing jabs and boasts at the other boys. He felt strong, fast, clever. More than that, he felt respected.

The King had not joined the games, of course, but his presence loomed. His eyes were always on Edric. Watching. Judging. Expecting.

But today, Edric didn’t care.

Today, he was nine years old—nearly a man.

And men did not need watching.

The Sword of a Prince

The formal ceremony came at midday, after the games had ended and the noble families had gathered in the Grand Hall. The air inside smelled of rich foods, braised venison and spiced wine, the warmth of countless bodies pressing against the cool stone walls. Banners of crimson and gold hung from the rafters, flickering in the candlelight.

Edric stood at the center of the hall, dressed in royal crimson, gold-threaded embroidery catching the light. His hands had been scrubbed raw again—he had tried to escape Brenna’s grip, but she had too much practice in catching him.

Before him, King Alistair stood tall, his fur-lined cloak draped over his shoulders, his expression carefully unreadable.

But Edric knew what was coming.

The hall quieted as a servant stepped forward, carrying a long wooden box.

Edric felt his pulse quicken.

This was the moment.

The servant set the box before him. Inside, nestled in dark velvet, was a sword.

Edric reached for it without hesitation.

It was lighter than he expected, though still solid, perfectly sized for his hands. The black leather hilt was smooth beneath his grip, the pommel carved with the sun sigil of Veridian. He turned the blade slightly, watching it catch the candlelight.

It was real.

A sword. His sword.

The hall murmured with approval.

His father stepped closer. “Do you understand what this means, Edric?”

He grinned up at him, tilting the sword in his hands. “That I’m allowed to stab people now?”

A ripple of laughter spread through the crowd.

His father did not smile.

Edric forced his expression to turn serious. “That I will learn to fight. To protect the kingdom.”

Alistair nodded once, but his gaze was sharp. “More than that.”

He placed a firm hand on Edric’s shoulder. “A sword is not a toy, nor a trinket for a prince to carry lightly. It is a responsibility.”

Edric nodded quickly.

His father continued, voice lowering. “You will learn the weight of power, Edric. You will learn when to strike, and when to stay your hand. A sword should never be drawn in arrogance, nor wielded without purpose.”

Edric stood straighter.

He felt the eyes of the nobles on him. He felt the weight of expectation pressing down on him like armor.

“I understand, Father,” he said.

A King’s Fear, A Prince’s Defiance

Edric was still gripping his sword when the celebration quieted again.

The King remained standing, looking out over the gathered nobles, but his next words were meant only for Edric.

“You will remain within the palace from now on.”

Edric froze.

“What?” His voice came out louder than intended, a flicker of frustration flashing in his chest.

His father’s expression was stone. “I will not have you wandering the city any longer.”

Edric felt heat rise in his face. “But I haven’t even—”

“This is not up for discussion,” his father cut him off, voice sharp.

The nobles were watching.

Edric’s grip tightened on the hilt of his sword. His chest felt hot, embarrassed, angry.

“But Father—”

Alistair stepped forward, towering over him now. “Do you think I do this to punish you?”

Edric clenched his jaw. “I think it’s weak.”

A silence fell over the room.

Edric knew immediately he had crossed a line.

His father’s face did not change. Did not harden, did not show anger. But the weight of him was crushing.

Slowly, he lowered his voice. “You will remain within the palace,” he repeated. “And you will learn what it means to be obedient.”

Edric bit back his frustration.

This was supposed to be his day.

A Different Kind of Gift

The tension did not last long.

The King returned to his seat, the nobles resumed their meals, and soon the music started again.

Edric was still fuming, sitting stiffly at the high table, when his father turned to him.

"Come."

Edric hesitated but obeyed.

He followed his father through one of the side doors of the hall, into a quieter chamber. A handful of nobles followed, but the space was more intimate, away from the watching eyes of the court.

At first, Edric wasn’t sure what was happening.

Then, he heard the whine of something small.

His head snapped up.

From behind one of the servants, a tiny black puppy bounded forward, paws too big for its body, tail wagging furiously.

Edric’s mouth parted slightly.

His father’s voice was quiet but firm. “He will grow to be a hunter, a protector. A loyal companion.”

The puppy tumbled over his own feet, then scrambled upright, bolting toward Edric.

Edric dropped to his knees just as a wet nose pressed into his palm. The puppy’s fur was thick and sleek, his dark eyes intelligent and full of energy. He snorted, sneezed, then immediately tried to climb into Edric’s lap.

Edric laughed. A full, unguarded sound.

His father watched.

Edric met his gaze.

The warmth was there—buried beneath duty, beneath fear—but there.

"Does he have a name?" Edric asked, running his hands over the pup's tiny, rounded ears.

His father tilted his head slightly. "That is for you to decide."

Edric grinned.

"Then his name is Varick."

His father’s breath huffed in amusement.

"Try again."

Ending Scene Visuals:

  • Edric laughing, the puppy squirming excitedly in his arms.

  • Alistair watching, his face unreadable—but softer than before.

  • The celebration carrying on in the distance, but for this moment, the world is just a boy and his dog.

What This Scene Accomplishes:

  1. Edric’s defiance grows. He challenges his father openly, believing fear is weakness.

  2. Alistair’s fear turns into control. He confines Edric to the palace, reinforcing his growing paranoia.

  3. A contrast of duty and warmth. The sword is a responsibility, but the puppy is unconditional.

  4. Foreshadowing. Edric will not stay confined forever. And he will not always obey.

Shit.

Her breath came fast, sharp. The man made a strange sound, like the wheeze of a broken bellows, before his legs gave out. His knees hit the ground hard, hands clutching at his belly, but the blood was already seeping through his fingers, already soaking into the cracks of the cobblestone.

She stared.

I killed him.

Her blade had sunk to the hilt.

She had felt the resistance, the resistance when it hit cloth, then broke the skin, how muscle clenched around the steel before it gave way, past whatever was inside a man.

The alley was too quiet. The sound of the parade still echoed from the main streets, drums, the ringing of bells, the distant cheer and chatter of the crowd. But here, in this narrow, shadowed stretch of stone and filth, there was only the wet, gasping breath of the man in front of her.

His fingers clutched at her wrist, his eyes wide, not quite believing what was happening.

She had been picking pockets all morning, moving through the crowd like a wisp of smoke, light-fingered and unseen. She had done it a hundred times. But this fucker had noticed.

She had run.

He had chased.

Now, she had won.

His weight slumped against her, and she barely managed to yank the knife free before he collapsed onto the cobblestones.

She took a step back.

Blood oozed from his belly, dark and thick, pooling beneath him. His mouth opened, breath coming in ragged gasps. He tried to say something, but no sound came out.

Arana’s heart was pounding.

Her breath came too fast, her hands were slick around the handle of the knife.

“Run!”

“Move!” She shouted at herself.

But she couldn’t look away.

His eyes were locked onto hers.

Then, finally—they emptied.

 

The parade roared behind her, a world away. Voices laughed and sang for the prince’s birthday, for a queen they didn’t even remember.

But here, in this alley, it was just her.

And him. And the sickening stench of iron and piss.

The knife in her hand felt different now. It wasn’t just hers—it was something else, too. A piece of him was on it. In it.

She forced herself to breathe. Move Arana. She wiped the blade roughly against the hem of her cloak with clumsy fingers, before shoving it back into the small leather sheath at her belt.

Who was he? A merchant? A father? A churchman?

A Wild magician?

Did it matter?

Something twisted in her gut, but she pushed it down, shoved it deep where it couldn’t touch her. She had no time for this.

She had to go.

Her hands felt too warm, sticky where his blood had flown over them. She wiped them fast against her tunic, but the feeling didn’t go away.

She turned and ran.

Ending Scene Visuals:

  • The body, cooling in the alley, unnoticed.

  • Arana moving through the crowds, faster than before, but not frantic—just enough to disappear.

  • The bells still ringing, the celebration still roaring. The world didn’t stop for him. It didn’t stop for her.

What This Scene Accomplishes:

  1. Raw, immediate emotion. Less self-reflection, more reaction.

  2. No moralizing. She doesn’t know what to feel—she doesn’t have time to.

  3. The city moves on. No one saw, no one noticed. He was just gone.

Refinement Questions:

Does Arana’s reaction to the killing feel natural for an eight-year-old who has been hardened by the streets?

  • Should she dwell on it more, or does she shake it off too easily?

Does the moment of pride feel appropriate, or should it be more fleeting?

  • Should it be buried under more shock and fear, or is it important that she acknowledges it?

Is there enough visceral detail in the actual act of stabbing?

  • Would a sharper focus on sensory details (the warmth of blood, the give of flesh, the sound of the man’s breath hitching) heighten the impact?

How do we want the reader to feel about Arana in this moment?

  • Should they be unsettled by her, or rooting for her? Or both?

Should there be a hint of the parade’s presence even in the alley?

  • Faint sounds of distant music or cheering—something to contrast the quiet, brutal moment?

Does the pacing work?

  • Should the struggle before she kills him last a little longer to build tension, or is the quick kill more effective?

 

Scene 2: The House Is Not a Sanctuary

The door slammed behind her, rattling in its frame.

Arana stood in the dim light of the house, her breath ragged, her hands still sticky with blood. She had tried wiping them clean on the way back—tried rubbing them against the rough fabric of her cloak, against the stone walls as she passed—but it hadn’t been enough. The stain clung. The scent was in her nose, her hair, her skin.

Her stomach twisted. She didn’t feel sick. Not exactly. But something was wrong inside her, something tight and tangled and too much.

The parade had been loud, but this—this was louder in a way she couldn’t escape.

I killed him.

She clenched her fists, nails pressing into her palms, grounding herself. Stop it. There was no time for thinking.

She moved quickly, shrugging off her cloak and bundling it up, shoving it under the loose floorboards near the hearth. She would burn it later. Maybe. She wasn’t sure.

Footsteps outside.

Her pulse spiked, but before she could react, the door swung open.

Liam stepped in first, brows raised, already grinning—until his eyes landed on her. He stopped short.

“Shit.”

Grizz followed behind, slower, heavier. His eyes swept over the room before settling on her.

Arana braced herself.

She had expected anger. Had expected shouting. Maybe even disgust.

But Grizz just looked at her. Calm. Assessing. Like he had known this would happen eventually.

Liam, though—Liam was different. His gaze flicked from her face to her hands to the dark stains on her tunic. His grin returned, sharp with interest.

“Well,” he said, nodding toward her bloody fingers, “this obviously went sideways.”

Arana swallowed hard.

Neither of them asked if she was hurt. They would have known if she was—if it was her blood instead of someone else’s.

She didn’t know what to say.

Grizz moved first, stepping inside, shutting the door behind him. He didn’t speak. Just walked past her, crouching near the hearth to stir the coals back to life.

Liam, on the other hand, leaned against the doorframe, arms crossed.

“So,” he said casually, “whose blood is it?”

She hesitated.

Grizz barely glanced over his shoulder. “She’ll tell us when she’s ready.”

Liam scoffed. “You’ll tell us now.”

Arana’s jaw clenched.

It wasn’t shame that kept her silent. Not exactly. It was something else.

But they weren’t looking at her like she had done something wrong.

Liam was curious.

And Grizz—Grizz was just waiting.

Like he already knew exactly how this felt.

She licked her lips, tasting salt and iron.

“…A man caught me picking his purse,” she admitted. “I ran. He chased me.”

Liam tilted his head, waiting.

Arana exhaled sharply. “I—I stabbed him.”

Liam let out a low whistle. “Damn.” He didn’t sound disturbed. If anything, he sounded impressed.

Arana’s shoulders tensed. “He would’ve killed me.”

Grizz didn’t react right away. He was still tending the fire, his hands steady as he worked.

Finally, he spoke. “Good.”

Arana blinked.

Grizz didn’t look at her, but his voice was even when he said, “You did what you had to do.”

It should have made her feel better. It didn’t.

Liam dropped into one of the chairs, kicking his feet up. “What was it like?” he asked.

Arana frowned. “What?”

“You know.” Liam made a vague gesture. “The stabbing. First time’s gotta be weird, right?”

She stared at him.

His grin widened. “Was it fast? Did he make a noise? Did it feel—”

“Liam.”

Grizz’s voice cut through the room like a blade.

Liam rolled his eyes. “I’m just saying—”

Grizz turned, finally looking at her fully. His expression was unreadable. “Are you still shaking?”

Arana hesitated. She hadn’t noticed it at first, but… yes.

Her fingers weren’t trembling, but something deep inside her was still humming.

Like she was waiting for something.

Like the fight wasn’t over yet.

She nodded once, stiffly.

Grizz gave a slow nod in return. “Good.”

Liam snorted. “What, that’s it? No big speech? No words of wisdom?”

Grizz stared at the fire for a moment before answering. “She’s not ready to hear them yet.”

Arana swallowed.

A strange, heavy silence settled between them.

She didn’t hate it.

Scene 3 – The Past

Location: Outside Arana’s House, on an old tree stump
Time of Day: Late afternoon, the sun sinking low, golden light filtering through the rooftops
Time of Year: Early autumn, the air growing colder as the sun fades
Weather: A chill creeping into the air, the scent of woodsmoke and damp earth
POV Character: Arana
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few hours

Arana sat hunched over a scrap of paper, charcoal smudging her fingers. She wasn’t thinking about what she was drawing, she was just letting her hands move, tracing the memory that refused to leave her mind. A shadowed alley, the slumped figure, the blood pooling into the cracks of the stone. The details etched themselves onto the page without her having to think about them.

She didn’t like thinking.

Not about what had happened. Not about how it had felt.

The air shifted beside her. She didn’t have to look up to know it was Grizz. He settled onto the ground next to her, his presence heavy but calm. He didn’t speak right away, just handed her a cup.

Arana blinked down at it. The smell of sour wine curled up from the rim.

“Drink,” he said.

She hesitated. She’d had wine before—stolen sips from Grizz or Liam, never much, never enough to care—but this felt different.

Still, she took a small sip. It burned, but at least it gave her something else to focus on.

Grizz gestured at the drawing in her lap. “That help?”

Arana nodded. She didn’t trust her voice. The adrenaline had long since drained from her, leaving something hollow in its place. If she spoke, she might shake. If she shook, she might cry. And she wasn’t going to cry.

Grizz sighed, stretching his legs out in front of him. “First time’s always the hardest,” he said. “No matter how much you tell yourself it’s just survival.”

She glanced at him, wary.

He wasn’t looking at her. His gaze was fixed somewhere in the distance, like he was seeing something long past.

“I was young too,” he said. “Older than you, but not by much. Got cornered in an alley by some bastard who thought I looked like easy pickings. I wasn’t.” His jaw flexed. “Didn’t have a knife then. Just my hands and a broken bottle.”

Arana’s grip on her cup tightened.

“He bled out fast. Too fast. I remember watchi’ him, waitin to feel... I dunno. Somethin different. Waitin for it to sink in.” Grizz let out a short, humorless laugh. “And when it did? Fuck, I was scared. But I was proud, too. Cause I was still standin. And he wasn’t.”

Grizz turned to look at her then. “You feel it, don’t you?”

She didn’t answer.

He nodded anyway. “Good. Don’t pretend you don’t.” He shifted, rubbing a hand over his knee. “But don’t let it make you cold, either. If you stop feelin, you start forgettin what it means to be human.”

Arana stared down at her drawing.

She wasn’t sure what to say to that.

They sat in silence for a long moment. The distant sounds of the city filled the quiet, dogs barking, voices carrying on the wind, the occasional clang of metal from somewhere in the city.

Then, without really thinking, she asked, “What happened to you, Grizz?”

He was still for a moment.

Then, slowly, he let out a breath.

“I had a wife once,” he said. “And a daughter.”

 

Grizz kept his gaze on the horizon. His voice was steady, but there was something heavy beneath it.

“We lived up north. Had a small farm, just the three of us. Grew what we needed, sold the rest to merchants passin through. Hunted, foraged. Had a few animals. It was enough.” His fingers curled slightly against the cup. “We were happy.”

“Then my wife got sick.” His voice dropped lower. “Fever took her fast. Nothin I could do.” He exhaled sharply. “Siva was just a year old. Tiny little thing.”

Arana’s chest tightened.

Grizz finally looked at her, his eyes unreadable. “She was like your parents.”

A cold weight settled in her stomach and Arana froze.

Grizz let out a quiet breath. “That’s why we left Sovalis in the first place. Out there, away from people, we could be safe. But I couldn’t teach her. I don’t have magic. I didn’t know how.” He ran a hand over his beard. “So, I brought her back here. And I found your parents.”

“They helped us,” Grizz said. “Aelius, Mirah, they taught her how to control it, how to hide it. Answered her questions. I needed them.” His throat bobbed. “And they helped gladly.”

Grizz smiled faintly. “Your parents were good people, Arana. Better than this fuckin’ world deserved. So full of love. Their house was always warm, always filled with light and laughter.”

Warmth flickered through her at the words. A whisper of something distant. Of glowing lights and stories.

Grizz inhaled slowly, sounding tired.

“And then they came.”

Arana’s stomach twisted.

“It was barely morning,” he muttered. “Woke to ‘em breakin’ down my door. Or maybe to her. Siva. Whisperin’ my name.”

Grizz’s fingers curled tight around the cup in his hands. “I don’t remember the whole fuckin’ thing,” he muttered. “Not straight through. Ain’t like a story in some fancy noble’s book. Just pieces. Pieces I can’t forget no matter how much I try.”

Arana watched him, silent.

“She was tuggin’ at me. ‘Papa, someone’s here.’” His voice was hoarse. “Didn’t even get the sleep outta my fuckin’ eyes before they grabbed me. Tore her right outta my arms and me outta bed like I was a fuckin’ dog.”

His jaw clenched. “Didn’t fight. Not at first. Was too busy lookin’ for her. Where’s my girl? Where’s my girl? Then I saw ‘em. Haulin’ her out the door. Her little hands wrapped around that damn doll she never let go of.” His breath came short. “And I lost it. I fuckin’ lost it.”

“I don’t remember what I said,” he admitted. “Don’t remember much after that ‘cept pain. Hands on me. A boot to the head. Gettin’ dragged outside, hearin’ the crowd cheerin’ like it was some godsdamned festival.” He exhaled sharply. “Like it was a fuckin’ celebration.”

The wind rustled through the streets, distant voices carrying over the rooftops.

“They tied her up first, there were other poor souls too, women and girls” he said, voice rough. “Didn’t tie me. Just held me down. Said I needed to watch. That I needed to see.” His grip on the cup went white-knuckled. “Saw the bastard in the robes step forward, big fucking ring on one hand, torch in the other. Did… something. And the torch suddenly burned.”

His breath came slower now, deeper.

“I begged,” he said. “Like a coward. Not even for me. Just for her.” His voice was hoarse. “Told’em that she doesn’t understand. Said she’s just a little girl. Said anything, I could think of that might make ‘em stop.”

A beat of silence.

“They laughed.”

Arana felt her chest go tight.

“I remember thinkin’… maybe she’d get lucky. Maybe the gods would strike ‘em down. Maybe I’d wake up and this’d be a fuckin’ dream.” His voice dropped lower. “Then the torch went near her. And she screamed.”

He swallowed hard, shaking his head. “It happened fast. That’s what people don’t tell you ‘bout wild magic. Ain’t slow, not when it comes from deep inside.” His jaw flexed. “One second, she’s just cryin’. Next second, there’s this pressure in the air. This weight in my face. And then…” He exhaled, his voice barely above a whisper. “…then the fire.”

Arana didn’t speak.

“Knocked the whole damn lot of ‘em back,” he muttered. “Inquisitor tripped over his own stupid robes. The torches went out like someone’d snuffed a candle.” His gaze was locked on something distant, something she couldn’t see. “And then the flames came back. But not theirs. Hers. I could feel it. Feels different y’know?”

He let out a slow, unsteady breath.

“She was strong, like her mother” he murmured. “Stronger than I knew. Too strong.”

The silence stretched, long and heavy.

“I woke up in ashes,” he muttered. “No idea how long I was out. Few hours maybe? The people had gone home. The church fuckers had dragged off the bodies. And me? They just left me there. Like trash.”

“I don’t remember gettin’ up,” he admitted. “Don’t remember crawlin’ to the stake. But I must’ve. Sat there for a long time. Just sat. Stared at what was left. Nothing was.” He swallowed hard. “And then they came back. Not to finish me. Just to throw me in a cell and let me rot for a couple years.”

Arana’s hands curled in her lap.

He turned to her then, his eyes dark.

“I never told anyone, “He said. “Not about her, not about my wife Lia, and not about your parents.”

“I don’t know about you, Arana,” he admitted. “But I got a feelin’.”

Arana’s chest ached.

“And I don’t know why they came for ‘em,” he muttered. “Maybe someone turned ‘em in. Maybe the cursed Church just knew.”

A weight settled in Arana’s stomach.

Her voice barely broke a whisper.

“It was my fault.”

 

Scene 4 – A Memory that Won’t Fade

Location: Outside Arana’s House, the same tree stump
Time of Day: Late afternoon, the sun beginning to set, casting long shadows
Time of Year: Early autumn, the air crisp with the coming cold
Weather: A biting wind picking up, swirling dust through the narrow streets
POV Character: Arana
Time Passed Since Previous Scene: A few moments

Grizz stared at her. Hard. His brows drew together, his mouth set in a deep frown.

“The fuck are you talkin’ about?”

Arana clenched her fists, her nails digging into her palms. Her whole body was tight, her breath coming too fast.

“It was me,” she said. “I got them caught.”

Grizz scoffed, shaking his head. “Horseshit.”

“No, it’s not,” she snapped, her voice rising. “You don’t get it. I never listened. Not once.” She curled her arms around herself. “They told me, over and over, that we had to be careful. That we had to move fast, keep our heads down, not draw attention.”

Her throat felt tight.

“But I didn’t care. I never cared.” Her voice cracked on the words.

Grizz didn’t say anything, just watched her, his fingers twitching against his knee.

“We were at the market,” she went on, her words tumbling out too fast, like she was afraid they’d get stuck if she didn’t force them. “I wanted to look at the ribbons—stupid fucking ribbons—and I pulled my mother over to the stall. I knew my father wouldn’t stop until we had everything we needed, I knew we were supposed to leave right after. But I saw them, and I didn’t care.”

Her hands trembled. She gritted her teeth and balled them into fists to stop it.

“If I hadn’t done that, we would’ve left sooner. We wouldn’t have still been there when that man—” She inhaled sharply. “He knocked me down. My father got mad, and then—”

She looked away, staring at the ground, at the dirt and dust beneath her feet.

“Then he used it.”

The words came out in a whisper.

Grizz shifted beside her, but she didn’t look up.

“He didn’t mean to. It was an accident. But it happened. And someone saw.” She exhaled sharply. “But we went home. We thought we were safe.”

Her breath shook.

“Then the guards came.”

A long silence stretched between them.

Grizz’s voice was low when he spoke. “And you think that’s your fault?”

She nodded.

He exhaled hard through his nose, shaking his head. “Kid, that ain’t how this works.”

“Yes, it is!” she snapped. “If I hadn’t stopped, if I hadn’t pulled my mother over, if I hadn’t—”

Grizz cut her off.

“If, if, if.” His voice was sharp, rough. “You wanna sit here ‘n’ tell me you got ‘em killed? That it was your fault the godsdamned church came for ‘em?”

She glared at him, her chin jutting forward. “It was.”

“No, it wasn’t.”

Arana dug her nails into her palms, looking away.

She wanted to believe him, but the feeling was still there. That weight pressing against her ribs, making it hard to breathe.

She clenched her jaw.

“I should’ve just…”

“Stop that.”

Grizz’s voice was firm, no patience left in it.

She snapped her head up, glaring. “Stop what?”

He leaned in slightly, his eyes sharp. “You think if you keep blamin’ yourself, it’ll make things make sense? That if you carry it, the world’ll feel fairer?” His voice was low, steady. “It won’t.”

Arana swallowed hard.

Grizz sighed, rubbing a hand over his beard. When he spoke again, his tone was rough but softer.

“Listen, kid.” He nudged her knee with his knuckles. “You didn’t kill your parents. You didn’t burn ‘em, you didn’t tie ‘em to those stakes. They did.” His voice dropped lower, heavy with meaning. “And they’ll do it again.”

“They don’t need a reason, Arana,” Grizz continued. “You think if it hadn’t been that day, it wouldn’t have been another? You think they wouldn’t have found some other godsdamned excuse?” He shook his head. “You don’t control them. You don’t control what they do, what they want.”

Her breath came shallow.

“They wanted your parents dead ‘cause they were better than them. Stronger than them. ‘Cause they had power the church couldn’t leash. Just like my girl did.” His voice was full of something dark now. “And the church don’t like what it can’t control.”

The words hit something deep.

“They were always gonna come, kid.” His voice softened. “You think if you’d walked faster, if you’d kept your mouth shut, they wouldn’t have found another way?”

Arana’s fists loosened slightly.

Grizz huffed. “You wanna carry somethin’? Carry that.” He gestured out toward the city, toward the Cathedral spires barely visible in the distance. “Carry the truth of what they are. Not some bullshit lie that makes you feel like you had a say in any of it.”

Arana swallowed. The sinking feeling was still there. But something sharper had settled next to it.

Grizz eyed her, reading something in her expression.

Finally, he stood, stretching his back with a grunt. “Now quit mopin’ and come inside. I ain’t wastin’ the rest of this good wine sittin’ out in the cold.”

Arana didn’t move right away.

The wind cut around her, pushing her hair into her face. She brushed it back, her fingers shaking less than before.

She looked at the drawing she had made, tore it to pieces and let the wind take them, scatter them.

She wasn’t sure if she believed Grizz.

But she wasn’t sure she didn’t.

And maybe, for now, that was enough.
